reviewText:
Some of these things actually happened.

But probably not many of them. At least not in any way close to the presentation in American Hustle.

That doesn't stop it from being an excellent movie, though.

It's one of the few movies I've seen where I had no idea about what was coming next. At its base, it's a con movie, so you're never quite sure who's conning whom and what anyone has up his sleeve. Or under her skirt, I suppose, since the women are perpetually dressed as they are in the poster. And, then, at least a couple of the characters are at least slightly unhinged, and you never quite know which direction the story is going.

Surprisingly, the movie opens with one of those flash-forward/flashback type things that I normally hate, but they really made it work in this one. For one thing, the movie doesn't start near the climax, just at the point of the first sting operation. It's the place where we meet all of the major players, so to speak. Once the deal falls apart, we flashback with Irving Rosenfeld for a first person narration (which I also usually hate) of what brought him to that point. But what makes it interesting is that when we get to the part where he crosses paths with Sydney Prosser, she picks up the narration and, then, they have this kind of dueling narration giving us the back story, and it really works. It helps that it's not a "36 hours earlier" kind of scenario. It's the characters telling us about who they are, you know, as people, and that's what makes it work.

As interesting as the story is, though, it's the acting that makes this movie. The performances, all of them, are incredible.

Christian Bale shows us once again just what he's willing to do physically to become his character, this time putting on a bit of a paunch (which he shows off in the movie in a very unflattering way) and shaving a bald spot onto his head (also unflattering). He's what can only be described as a sleazy character, a con man, but, by the time we get back to the point in the story where it started, we have total sympathy for him. I just want to point out that I am not a Bale fan. I have respect for what he's willing to go through for a role (like in The Machinist and Rescue Dawn), and I think he's a good actor, but I don't really like him that much. That I say he was impressive in this role is, then, saying something.

Amy Adams--cute, sweet Amy Adams--shows us she's anything but as an ex-stripper trying to reinvent herself. Her boobs should probably also have received some sort of credit. Not that they ever fully appear onscreen or anything, but it's hard not to be aware of them when she's onscreen. She's like some 70s porn star or something. Or like what I think a 70s porn star must have been like. I'm not really sure. At any rate, her performance is pretty amazing, and you're never quite sure what she's up to, just that she is up to... things. It's her performance that provides a lot of the tension in the movie, because you're never really sure whose side she's on. Well, other than her own, that is.

Bradley Cooper is amazing as a somewhat overzealous FBI agent. And I'd say more about him, but I don't think I can without spoilers. I'll just say that I think Cooper has a certain intensity about him that not many actors can equal. And, according to my wife, he and Adams deliver one of the sexiest scenes she's ever seen. The amazing thing about that is that nothing happens in that scene. Well, not nothing but, you know, nothing happens: there is no loss of clothing or anything like that. But it's intense, and most of that is from him.

Jennifer Lawrence continues to show that she's more than just a pretty face. I'm not quite sure she deserved her Oscar last year (not that her performance wasn't good; it was. I've just never been convinced it was "best actress" quality), but, if she gets a best supporting Oscar for this role, it will be deserved. The scene with her and the "science oven" is almost enough all by itself to earn her the Oscar.

And, then, there's Jeremy Renner. And his hair. Because if Amy Adams boobs almost deserved a screen credit, Renner's hair certainly did. I could not take my eyes off of it. It was amazing. And, in a movie where everyone's hair was pretty amazing, that's saying something. This is the first movie I've seen him in where he shows me he can do something besides play "taciturn hero" (and, no, I haven't yet seen The Hurt Locker, but, knowing what it's about (loosely), I'm guess he plays "taciturn hero" in that one, too). He's pretty great as a New Jersey mayor in this. He's pretty great in the sense that I did not actually know he was in the movie before I was seeing the movie, and, then, I kept wondering if I was wrong and maybe that wasn't really him, so that, I think, is a pretty good performance.

Louis C.K. also fit in nicely. I don't think there was any kind of stretch for him as an actor, but he worked well with everyone else. As did Elisabeth Rohm (from Angel); I didn't recognize her at all.

The end result is a lot of compelling performances and an interesting plot. Enough so that, as I sit here writing this up, it makes me want to watch it again. Especially Jeremy Renner's hair. I don't think I've been so captivated by anyone's hair since the Dallas Cowboys won the Super Bowl back in '93 (I think) and someone (Emmitt Smith?) poured a cooler of water over Jimmy Johnson's head, and his hair didn't move. It was like he had on a plastic, hair-shaped helmet. It was fascinating.

Oh! And the cameo appearance by De Niro... the perfect touch.

Some fine actors with bad clothing. Sexy women. A great scary cameo, one of the best scenes in the movie. But after all the hype, a real disappointment. Didn't come close to "The Sting" for trickery. Didn't connect with or find the characters interesting. How anyone would buy into their schemes is beyond belief. I live near some of the shooting locations, that was cool. It can wait for cable.
PS. Best bad hair was Bill Murray in "Kingpin"

First we see: "Some of this really happened." And it's true. This chaotic R-rated mess was inspired by the late 70s Abscam mess which involved the FBI, the Mafia, a Middle Eastern Sheik and many elected officials. I never got it straight when it was happening and I scarcely did much better today.

Nominated for seven (7!) Golden Globes: Best Picture - Comedy or Musical; Best Actor and Actress; Best Supporting Actor and Actress; Best Director and Best Screenplay. I would suggest they also include Best Hair. In my opinion this one is head and shoulders above many other high-profile films because it's so much fun! Director David O. Russell ("The Fighter") keeps things humming along and draws extremely natural performances from his cast.

We enjoy:
  * Christian Bale ("The Dark Knight") as Irving (the names have been changed to protect the innocent), a two-bit flim-flam man lured into an entrapment scheme by an ambitious FBI agent. This time Bale is a stooped, paunchy, married schlub with the most tortured toupee and cockamamie comb-over I have ever seen.
  * Jennifer Lawrence ("Silver Linings Playbook") is his wife Rosalyn, who knows Irving has a mistress but can't see why that should have any effect on their marriage. He has adopted her son and doesn't want to lose him. Her hairdo is a stylist's combo of "Big Hair" and "Outrageous Hair." She HATES that new-fangled "science oven" (microwave) because she ignored the warning and tried to heat a foil container. Eek!
  * Amy Adams ("Her") is Sidney, Irving's partner in crime, both in and out of bed. Sometimes she's British, sometimes she's from Albuquerque. We see a LOT of Sidney in this one! She spends a lot of time with her hair in huge rollers.
  * Bradley Cooper ("The Hangover") is Richie, the manic FBI man. He moves the outlandish plot forward by sheer force of will and is unforgettable with his hair in those teeny permanent wave rollers. Cooper and Adams generate some real sexual heat in this one. Whew!
  * Michael Pea ("End of Watch") is Paco, a Hispanic from California recruited to play the Sheik. His hair is covered by a pseudo white cloth with a black band to make him look Middle Eastern.
  * Jeremy Renner ("The Town") is the Mayor. He is the only (sorta) "Good Guy" in the bunch, with a glamorous wife and five children, all of whom he adores. Check out his heroic pompadour!

Kudos to Susan Jacobs for assembling the wonderful sound track: Everything from Duke Ellington and Steely Dan to "Yellow Brick Road" and "Live and Let Die." Loved it!

This has a satisfying wrap-up and I left the theater vowing to look up Abscam as soon as I got home. (I'll want to know more about it before the Academy Awards roll around, when it is sure to come up again.) Amazon will notify me when it's available on DVD.

David O. Russell has become a household name in Hollywood and also amongst many avid moviegoers. While hes had several projects over the years, he really bust on to the scene in 2010 as the director of The Fighter  which starred Christian Bale and Amy Adams, both of whom were nominated for multiple awards for their individual supporting roles (Bale won both an Academy Award and Golden Globe). Flash forward two years and that brings us to 2012 where Russell once again made his mark on the big screen by penning the script (originally created by Matthew Quick) and directing Silver Linings Playbook. The film starred Bradley Cooper and Jennifer Lawrence, both of whom earned several nominations for various awards of their own (Lawrence won both an Academy Award and Golden Globe). Now, here we are one year later as these four well-established actors star in Russells newest film, American Hustle.

In American Hustle, Christian Bale stars as a con artist named Irving Rosenfeld. One day, he meets an attractive woman at a party named Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams), who he immediately falls for and brings in to his racket. Together, the two are so successful conning people (approving loans, selling fake art, etc.) that it attracts the FBI. Sydney, working alongside Irving under a false name, is busted and taken into custody by an ambitious agent, named Richie DiMaso (Bradley Cooper). In order to clear Sydneys name, Irving and Sydney must work undercover alongside Richie to complete four major busts.

Posing with the fake financial backing of the foreign Sheik Abdullah (Michael Pea), the trio goes into business with the crooked New Jersey Mayor, Carmine Polito (Jeremy Renner). The beloved, yet crooked Mayor has a vision of returning Atlantic City to prominence and also creating thousands of new jobs. However, in order to do so, he must secure finances  which means he is willing to partner-up with the mob. The backroom dealings with the mob also require a few acts of Congress, leading to the eventual bribing of a handful of Congressmen and one Senator. However, the only thing that can screw everything up is Irvings wife, Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence), who has a flare for the dramatic and constantly requires attention.

From the moment this film begins until the very end, its relatively safe to say theres no film in the history of cinema that depicts this much hustling, cheating, and lying. In the event that any one of the characters walked into a church, it would positively go up in flames. Irving is hustling Sydney, and she loves him for it. Rosalyn is hustling Irving, and he hates her for it. Richie hustles Sydney and Irving, while Sydney is constantly hustling Richie. Richie and company are hustling the mob, the Mayor, and members of Congress  and the FBI is behind all of it. There is literally no one in this film that isn't hustled at one point or another.

To that end, you need accomplished actors and actresses that are capable of selling these onscreen hustles, and with that being said, there might not be a more perfect ensemble in the history of filmmaking than the four individuals featured in this film. David O. Russell clearly had the unspeakably brilliant epiphany to bring the four highly acclaimed cast members from The Fighter and Silver Linings Playbook together for one incredible feature. He even sneaks in (SPOILER) Robert De Niro from a perfectly timed cameo. And, the end result is a masterful work of art.

Christian Bale is the focal point of this character-driven story. For whatever reason, Bale needed to be overweight and balding for the role and also suffers from a serious heart condition. However, before you jump to any conclusions, it should be noted that none of these elements are vital to the story. Bales character is too confident to let his physical appearance hinder his appetite for the hustle. And confident he most certainly is  proving hes almost too good to be caught. He lives his life through one of the films most prudent themes: the art of survival.

Jennifer Lawrence is obviously a huge star these days, especially since he roles The Hunger Games films, along with the X-Men films and Silver Linings Playbook. Those films are all fine and dandy, but they are targeted towards a particular audience and will likely succeed with or without her involvement. Lawrence proves her talent, not by shooting arrows at people, but by taking on serious, well-written dramatic roles. Once more, Lawrence steals each and every scene in which shes present (mostly with her humorous nut ball comments)  and she does so with such elegance. Like her role in Silver Linings Playbook, she portrays a mentally disturbed individual with serious emotional distress. Even though shes only present for a handful of scenes in this film, shes still a main attraction, even despite the scene dominance of her wondrous cast mates.

While its easy to see the outstanding performances of Christian Bale and Jennifer Lawrence, the impressive acting of Bradley Cooper and Amy Adams shouldnt go unnoticed. Neither gives an over-the-top, career defining performance, but they are equally acclaim worthy. Cooper, more so than Adams, shows just how far hes come in Hollywood  going from comedy to action and now fully establishing himself as a serious dramatic actor. Of course, Amy Adams is already a domineering presence in dramatic acting, so the fact that she puts on an amazing performance is no surprise at all. The scenes that Cooper and Adams share together are remarkably energetic, and are proof that despite what you may think you see, the hustle never ends. Never.

Overall, its not surprising that so many have praised America Hustle as one of the top films of 2013. Theres little doubt this film tries to make hustling look cool  and it succeeds. It also doesnt fail to make these ambitious characters look cool  with their flashy hair, scantily clad outfits, and smooth dialog. No, this film doesnt have the satisfying payoff that youd expect from a movie like Oceans 11, but it does prove that crime-centric films are still unbelievably entertaining. Obviously, there are drawbacks to seeing this film. Most notably, there is no action-packed shootouts or ridiculous CGI. American Hustle is simply a film where acting and character development come first, while everything else, like plot and tying up loose ends comes second. If drama is your fancy, this film will plain and simply knock your socks off.

GRADE:  A
FNDNreview.com

David O. Russell is my new favorite American movie director.
Silver Lining Playbook (2012) was good, and American Hustle (2013) ranks in just as good.
Last time I saw a WELL made movie in recent times take takes place in 1970's America was Boogie Nights (1997) and Lovelace (2012), but now that I saw American Hustle, I must say I am blown away by the fashion details, dialogue, and soundtrack of this movie.
Although, its music could have been even better if they had at least two songs by the KC & the Sunshine Band, such as:
"Keep it Comin' Love" or "Shotgun Shuffle", or "I like to Do it", and some Barry White wouldn't hurt either...it could have been 1970's boogie to the core.

Most importantly, what I like about this film is the cast (everyone is just brilliant in their role), and the dialogue, the script is prefect, the jokes smart and witty.  The touch of comedy incorporated into this film is pure genius.
I hope to see similar movies from Russell in the near future.

BTW: Jennifer Lawrence should accept more movie roles similar to the one she played in this film. She is only wasting her talent in BS Hunger Games franchise. Hey but I understand, movie stars need to appeal to the masses of people and make BS movies once in a while in order to rake in profits.

"American Hustle" (2013 release; 138 min.) opens with the reminder that "Some of this actually happened", after which we are transported to New York, April 1978, where the mayor of Camden NJ (played by Jeremy Renner) is apparently being set up in an FBI undercover sting operation of some sort. We see the main characters yet do not know who is who exactly. Then in a further flashback (along with voiceover), we get to know Irving (played by Christian Bale), who meets Sydney (played by Amy Adams) at a party. They hit it off on all levels, and soon the are doing various scams. Comments Sydney: "the more you say 'no' to people, the more they want in!". Unfortunately in one of those scams, the 'victim' was an undercover FBI agent named Richie (played by Bradley Cooper). Richie eventually convinces Irving and Sydney to help him uncover corrupt politicians, and they set in motion a giant scam. Apart from all that, we learn that Irving is actually married to Rosalyn (played by Jennifer Lawrence), who seems to be a 'dumb blond'. At this point we are barely 30 min. into the movie, but to tell you more would ruin your viewing experience, you'll just have to see for yourself how it all plays out.

Several comments: first and foremost, this movie is another tour de force for director David Russell, after last year's Silver Linings Playbook, and The Fighter the year before that. From the moment the movie opens, Russell pulls us in and won't let go until some 2 hours later. At some point in the movie it becomes impossible to tell who is manipulating whom, and you'll just let go and be surprised as the movie unfolds. Because of the nature and era of the movie, "American Hustle" feels like The Sting-meets-Taxi Driver-meets-The Godfather, just a delight from start to finish. Second, there are so many outstanding acting performances in this movie, I don't even know where to begin. As scheduling fate would have it, I saw Christian Bale just recently in "Out of the Furnace" and now in this, in two roles that couldn't be more different, yet he displays an incredible and confidant acting range reminiscent of, say, a younger Robert de Niro. Speaking of which: de Niro makes a small appearance (10 min. max) that is better than anything he has done in YEARS. Amy Adams has never looked more gorgeous than in this movie. And Jennifer Lawrence (just weeks after seeing her in The Hunger Games: Catching Fire) makes the most of her small role. Last, but certainly not least, the movie soundtrack (from the 70s) is nothing short of stellar. Check out the delightful scene where Sydney and Richie are dancing to Donna Summer's I Feel Love, and later when Rosalyn cleans the house while singing/dancing along to Paul McCartney's Live and Let Die. Sheer delight!

The movie opened today (yes, Thursday is the new Friday apparently) and I went to see it right away. The screening I saw this at here in Cincinnati was very well attended, I am happy to say. This movie truly is Hollywood at its very best: an intelligent, absorbing and yes, entertaining movie from start to finish, it could be for this year what "Argo" was for last year, frankly. "American Hustle" is HIGHLY, HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

A fictionalized account of the ABSCAM entrapment operation.  Most viewers will know the results.  The film aims to show how they happened.  Most of the characters are repulsive.  The film tries to lessen our distaste by making them funny.  Apart from a few good lines, the film is not very funny.  So it seems overly long.  Irv is a con man who teams up with a woman named Sydney.  Irv discovers that the best way to draw people into the con is to refuse them initially. They have great success until they are busted by the FBI early in the film.  They have a chance to avoid prosecution by helping the FBI entrap other con men, and the operation quickly escalates out of everyone's control as the FBI go for bigger and bigger fish.  In the end, the FBI  bring down a few people, some of whom might have been corrupt even without the cash the FBI passed them, but they botch the investigation and are conned by the con men.  The end was very well done, and Bale and Jennifer Lawrence put in very good performances.
Such a great movie with excellent performances and wonderful soundtrack. Looks like the director took a page out of the Martin Scorsese school of filmmaking, but, that's a good thing!

I can't remember if Amy Adams got an Oscar for this? She sure as heck deserves it though. I just read a couple of ridiculous reviews and want to say I really like this movie. Of course I grew up in the 70's. With Kangaroo sneakers with little side pockets. Doin' "The Hustle", and no I'm not talking about a con or card game. The 70's for kids was a really cool time. We had rollerskating parties at roller rinks and we rode our bicycles with banana seats and little plastic streamers coming out of the handle bars...right down the middle of the street! And everyone played outside. Times were good. John Travolta and The Bee Gee's ruled. So did Diana Ross. And man, people dressed up! They just put a whole lot more into it than now. Clothes and style really meant something back then. The music, the fashion, everything was filled with shine and spirit.

This movie is just plain fun. There are many hilarious scenes especially when Bradley Cooper takes a call from "Edith" and his mom yells at him to "get back here and pray properly!" Edith then finds out he has a fiance. Yep. This is great stuff.
Love the Ice fishing in October story. Who goes Ice fishing in October? Seriously.

I haven't gotten to the end yet but I have laughed so hard at this Arab Sheikh who is really a Mexican from Arizona and upset about Operation "Abscam" because he says it's racist. I love that actor too.

This movie is way funny. I think, you either get it, or you don't. I hope terrible things don't happen in the end. They kinda might though. I get the feeling that Christian Bale is gettin in tight with Jeremy Renner and he is trying to think of a way to warn him before Renner gets caught. You can just see it all over Christian. It's all so wrong to set Renner up and trap him like that. He really is a very decent good guy. Bradley Cooper's character is so naive and has visions of glory but he doesn't care who gets destroyed by his "ideas" of greatness at the FBI. These are real people he is entrapping. It can't end well for anyone.

Either way this movie belongs to Amy Adams. She is stellar. Jennifer Lawrence also really does a great job. Christian Bale and Bradley Cooper are awesome. But come on people, this is Amy's movie. I hope she got that Oscar.

With all of the Oscar nominations, I was expecting greatness, and I found it in American Hustle. The acting alone makes this movie worthwhile (I don't think there was a bad performance in the movie). Add in the beautiful costumes and fantastic cinematography, and you've got a movie worth watching time and again. That said, I found parts of it deeply sad. I don't think it's meant to be sad, but some of the character flaws were a bit depressing.
Could watch this movie over and over and over again.

Great acting and an entertaining story, very well done.  And what a cast.  Like much of the stuff that either came out of the 70s or portrays the 70s, however, there is a layer of grunge over the story, a depressing patina.  Having lived through the 70s I found most of it to be pretty depressing.  Watergate, the Vietnam war, the oil crisis, s***ty cars, horrible clothes, bad hair, ghastly architecture.  Thank God it's over.

Against my wishes but to please my lovely wife we paid good money to watch this idiotic film again. We saw it in the theater when it was released and I could not believe how many Academy Award nominations it received. But the Academy has been sinking for a long time along with most of Hollywood elite. Little is left of the glory days when good films were built on solid stories, good acting and superb directing. American Hustle had not of that. What it did have in almost every scene was nearly exposed breasts. Any movie that has a character in dresses and blouses that plunge as far as her navel and more in her every scene is a movie that is begging for eyeballs because there is no other reason to watch the movie. Amy Adams is pretty enough but she was as lame in this as in Leap Year. Christian Bale who has been top notch in most of his roles was stuck with paying a pathetic character in need of a bottle of booze and an retirement in a 1972 mobile home park. Bradley Cooper over played almost every scene...only in one did he really shine when it all crashed down around him. Jennifer Lawrence was wasted in this bore of a movie.

This is one of those things where everything comes together superbly! The story is a cracker, with a couple of low level fraudsters strong-armed into an FBI sting operation. Complications kick in and the stakes and tension rise. The good guys and bad guys take on shades of grey and there are some great surprises. The entire cast is excellent, Amy Adams is stunning in the 70s fashions, Brad Cooper makes them work great too. Jennifer Lawrence and Jeremy Renner offer wonderful surprises and Christian Bale is almost unrecognizable as the conflicted conman at the middle of it all. The script is excellent with some sizzling scenes and the costumes and the music perfect. This film has it all! It is vibrant and vivid, sexy and so cool  even on the second viewing! Very highly recommended!

David Russell is an director who enjoys showing the life of everyday characters and they way they interact with each other. Ordinary people are elevated to greatness in his films- just watch Silver Linings Playbook to see what I mean. American Hustle is a story about a few scammers and their scams but it is mostly about the different characters, their lives, their weaknesses, their strengths and the way they interact with their friends and families.

Christian Bale is amazing as a scammer and with Amy Adams as his equally crooked friend and partner they are sensational. You should feel revulsion towards these people but when you see their side stories and complicated lives - you start to understand their motives and intentions.
Bradley Cooper, though not as good as Silver Linings is still amazing. His character is also very well written and  is a about a man trying to be someone.
Jennifer Lawrence has a shorter role but she is a maniac- just too good. Jeremy Renner is Polito, a New Jersey mayor a good man who sometimes has to be dishonest.  I loved the way these characters come alive. They transform themselves completely

What an amazing ensemble of talent, and what remarkable costuming and story line. I love this movie for both those qualities - the visual and the story.  I rented this and wish I had just purchased it. Stunned it did not win any of the many Oscar nominations it was up for - at least Golden Globe Awards go it right. That was a year of fabulous movies though - so hard to pick maybe. This is a trip down late 70's memory lane and I enjoyed that part as well.  What I don't get is why it is described as a comedy. It is fabulously entertaining - never stops moving, and that chaos is definitely sympathetic with the characters and the plot. These are not calm people or events - lots of tension, lots of drama, lots of loose cannons going off. But comedy? Yes, there are some great moments that will make you smile but to me this is drama along the line of Wolf on Wall Street. I cannot imagine how any one would be disappointed watching this. And talk about beautiful people - even down to the bit part of John Huston, my goodness.

This was a much better movie than I'd anticipated. I rented this movie thinking it would be good & it was. So good that I then bought a copy. The ABSCAM thing was taking place as I was in college & graduating & working in local newsrooms and so, this movie was a trip down memory lane for me, complete with clothes & characters & hair. The cast was wonderful and the movie, fun to watch. But I don't think you need to have come of age in the late 70s to appreciate or enjoy American Hustle.

Truly a contemporary masterpiece. I have never seen a director capture the truth of human emotion and rhetoric as well as Russell does in this movie (as well as in Silver Linings). It's not at all easy to make a well-structured movie that deviates from cinematic customs and formulaic dialogue, yet this movie manages seamlessly. The characters are raw as lumber and both loveable and hateable, as all humans are; nobody tips perfectly to one side of the scale, and bad movies tend to have characters who can be easily polarized into the categories of "good" or "bad". Rosalyn Rosenfeld (Jennifer Lawrence), epitomizes the shaky nature of context and the classification of "good" versus "bad". The movie's darkest and funniest moments alike seem to be spurred by Rosalyn's maniacal actions, which are often ill-advised beyond belief but somehow forgivable due to her inherently reasonable emotional desires in life. This movie is a flawless amalgam of crime flick and drama: the plot is wrapped around the real-life Abscam scandal (very interesting, check it out on Wiki), a 1970s FBI plot which aimed to indict Congressmen and other government officials under corruption charges through the use of a fake Arabic "Sheik". The story, meanwhile -- which can be notably distinguished from the plot -- is about the power of reinventing yourself. This movie falls short in neither department -- the criminal drama is nothing short of enticing, while the emotional end is a rollercoaster of laughs and tears. Also, I was more than pleasantly surprised to find Louis CK make an appearance in the movie! FYI, he did not disappoint whatsoever. On a final note, I was in love with some of Russell's musical montages. There is a part in which Irving Rosenfeld (Christian Bale) and Carmine Polito (Jeremy Renner) are out dining with their wives, and the scene is an ecstatic collage of light musical dialogue, laughs, and a soft jazzy soundtrack. All in all, an excellent movie.

One of the best written stories made for the big screen thus movie we have ever seen. What a perfect confluence of script, cast, acting, direction, cinematography, soundtrack, and editing. It is near perfect. If ever there was a raging psycho made for film it is Mr. Cooper as we have seen now twice. Mr. Bale is almost unidentifiable confirming his truly incredibility range of character acting skills. And with a twin set of equally dangerous, voluptuous, and alluring femme fatales as Ms. Adams and Ms. Lawrence to contend with, it weaves the final beauty into the multi-layered plots and subplots and finally exposed real plot. WOW! The whole experience is of real Americans in all of their glory. Don't miss this one.

The story is so tightly focused on two women and two men with deep  and intensive personal problems and foibles, few of which my friends and I could identify with, and certainly more on pinpoint than the  title of "American Hustle" can convey.  Hustle it was, but at the level of the four main characters.  American it could hardly be; the personalities featured are not representative of some American values or aspirations, and they aren't examples of anything national in scope or revealing of anything with long-term promise.

I have to say that even though I had trouble following the storyline. I had trouble distinguishing between Christian Bale and Bradley Cooper in the film. They looked so much alike that they could be brothers even twins. I wasn't sure who was Irvin or Richie. Amy Adams and Jennifer Lawrence are superb in their roles. Jeremy Renner plays Mayor Carnine Polito, the Camden mayor who loved his family, wife, and city despite being corrupt. Louis C.K. is memorable in his role and I was trying to figure out who he was throughout the film. While at times, I felt Jennifer Lawrence was miscast for the role. She was too young to play Irvin's wife, Rosalyn. Amy Adams is superb as the mistress, con-artist, and player.

The cast is superb. I enjoy the art direction, costumes, music and the actors. I just had trouble with the storyline though. I wasn't sure who was conning who at times. Perhaps it was because Bradley Cooper and Christian Bale looked more like brothers and twins than adversaries.

The DVD has two notable features such as the making of the film and the deleted and extended scenes as well. Despite some flaws, I found the film entertaining overall. I wished they included a background feature to explain the actual events that occurred. The con was called "Abscam" to target corrupt politicians and officials. You have to wonder what happened to the characters after the story was over.

Absolutely beautiful motion picture with five utterly compelling performances. Amy Adams, the most beautiful woman in movies and the best actress on earth -- is that over the top? Well, not for me -- dazzles as the lost girl looking for her place in life. Christian Bale's grifter, whose profession soars when he enlists her Sydney/Edith character, gained about 90 pounds from the role he played in the movie "The Fighter." An ambitious, coke sniffing FBI agent played by Bradley Cooper catches them in a grift, then forces them to entrap some politicians in a take on the Ab-Scam scandal of the 1970s. But the end is worthy of "The Sting."

Christian Bale is America's most under-rated actor. This film is yet another example of his extraordinary range and subtle skills. And this is yet another film that confirms my ardent admiration for both Jennifer Lawrence and Amy Adams. They will no doubt continue to enjoy what they deserve: careers of artistic acclaim!

I actually was able to watch American Hustle after I had recently rented it from Redbox. American Hustle opens with the characters of Irving Rosenfeld (Christian Bale), Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams), Richie De Maso (Bradley Cooper), and Mayor Carmine Polito (Jeremy Renner) appearing to be in the midst of finalizing a deal.  Rosenfeld, Prosser, and De Masio are actually working together towards what is supposed to be mutual professional understanding. Rosenfeld and Prosser are in love with each other. However, Rosenfeld also has a wife Rosalyn Rosenfeld (Jennifer Lawrence) and kids at home that he also has to take into consideration. What complicates matters is that De Maso also appears to be taking romantic interest in Prosser. Irving Rosenfelds wife Rosalyn Rosenfeld is somewhat aware of her husbands life, but the movie portrays that there is still  so much she is unaware about. Bradley Cooper plays the integral role of an FBI agent who is orchestrating the talents of Sydney Prosser an Irving Rosenfeld due to their cunning ability to be professional con artists. Jeremy Renner plays a New Jersey mayor who is also caught in the web that is being weaved around a professional deal that is supposed to hold potential towards generating enormous profit.

I would put "American Hustle" amongst the better great American "crime" or "heist" movies from recent years, and it deserves comparison to the best of them.  It's probably also comparable to something like "Boogie Nights" as an entertaining 70's-80's period piece.  The plot and particularly the characters are very well written...one of those movies where the characters and story arc get pretty crazy, but you love every minute of it.  Christian Bale plays a slightly against type character (mainly because he sports a gut) but it ends up being one of his best roles.  Jennifer Lawrence and Brad Cooper are great too, along with the rest of the supporting cast and probably my favorite is Jeremy Renner as "the mayor."

I don't think anyone is claiming this story is completely historical; but it is based on the FBI's real-life 70's and 80's program whereby they infiltrated organized crime and corruptness carried on by US politicians.  In "Hustle" the FBI has recruited two ex-con artists (played by Christian Bale and Amy Adams), using duress, to help the FBI take down some of these corrupt politicians.  That's a quick synopsis of the plot, but there's lots of twists and turns and very entertaining dynamics that develop amongst the characters

All-in-all very entertaining, and at times hilarious!
Great movie!

This movie got so much hype and praise but honestly I don't really understand why. I'm not saying that it's a bad film, but it's not great, certainly didn't live up to all the great press that it got. The Plot itself was interesting but I felt like the whole movie was kinda going through the motions. No super stand out acting and I felt like it just fizzled out by the end. Basically, I feel like I watched it and then didn't really think about it again. Usually if a movie is good, I'll want to talk about it and I don't have much to say about "American Hustle."

"American Hustle" is an unapologetically glamorous, indulgent riff on classic Hollywood ensemble romps, set in the lately-resurgent so-uncool- they're-cool-again 1970s. Nearly every role, from the headliners to the bit parts to the cameos, are filled by some of the hottest, most critically-beloved actors of their generation, and they clearly relish rocking their ironically unhip (and therefore hip) comb-overs and ginormous glasses and outrageous blazers and tawdry-sexy dresses. There's no denying that the cinematography and the casting and the 70s- hits soundtrack are tailored to a tee. It screams, "Yes, I am a Big Hollywood Movie," and it knows it can pull that look off and we won't roll our eyes or look away. Very well, some of us will; there are those, in the run-up to the Oscars, who are calling it Oscar bait, suggesting that it's cynically ticking off the boxes the Academy wants to see ticked: Jennifer Lawrence, check; stars "selflessly" obfuscating themselves behind faux-ugly makeup, check; a throwback to a time today's Oscar voters are nostalgic for, check. The movie is all the more fun to watch because it has these things. But it has more than that, plenty enough to justify the awards it's gotten and the awards it will get. It's not the main plot, which is Capers 101 with some predictable twists. It's also not the gray areas or the subtexts, which by the end are surprisingly black and white and cut and dry. The extra mile is the characterizations, huge and clear-cut personalities that are also finely-detailed and reveal new layers with each scene. Everyone is flawed, but everyone is well-intentioned, and it's hard not to like all of them even as they cultivate sleazy, selfish dislikability. The characters' tangled relationships and personal battles reduce the 200 million dollar stakes of the principle con to a secondary concern, or perhaps it is more accurate to say that they give the con meaning beyond the merely monetary. In this, screenwriters David O. Russell (who also directed) and Eric Warren Singer hit the same notes that define the Coen brothers' films, except that Russell and Singer have a softer, more sentimental touch. It's "American Hustle"'s above-average writing, and the well-above-average acting required to sell such a script, that the Academy has recognized, and not just the movie's in-vogue surface qualities and shiny package.

Well, it is a rare thing to capture the spirit of an age and yet director David O. Russell has done that with this film. Give Russell credit; even if you didn't live through the decade, the movie's manic energy made you want to. The movie's plot involves the FBI's Abscam political corruption probe, which really isn't that important and it is best if you don't follow the plot too closely. If you do then you'll miss out on one of the best con movies to come out in many years. Honestly, we need to thank Russell for not taking the subject seriously (oh, how the movie could've dragged if he did). Instead, Russell infuses the film with an upbeat swagger that only a few films have equaled, such as The Sting (1973, George Roy Hill), Ocean's Eleven (2001, Steven Soderbergh), and The Hoax (2006, Lasse Halstrom). Russell has a stock company of actors with Bradley Cooper, Jennifer Lawrence, Christian Bale, and Amy Adams who would probably go to the moon for him if he asked. Examples: Cooper dons jerry-curls, Lawrence wears sweet yet smelly fingernail polish, Bale inhabits a pot belly and intense comb over, and Adams delivers a less-than-effective British accent. It's a toss-up who puts-in the best performance, but my vote is for Bradley Cooper. Cooper does get better and better in every movie he's in. Born to lose; he plays a hotshot FBI agent who harbors delusions of grand career climbing, but stumbles over his own ambitions. It almost sounds Shakespearean yet more fun. A notable instance of frustration includes Adams' annoying faux-British accent, which went in and out at both the right and wrong times and nowhere this year will you find a better opening scene.

I love this film.  It has plot twists, tricky situations, and a lot of pressure building up for our protagonists, who aren't really what they seem.  The soundtrack is excellent, as are the costumes.  The hustle/con is convincing for me.  I know there are detractors who think it's not very significant.  I get caught up in the moment every time I watch it.  The one annoying thing is Jennifer Lawrence, who seems inauthentic.  i think she was miscast.  Christian Bale is so impressive, how he inhabits this role and you lose track of the fact that he is Christian Bale - he is authentically playing his role - which is not an easy role to play.  I was expecting it to be a light film, but there is disappointment, compromise, and struggle all around.

Oh my god...  I watched "American Hustle" pop-eyed and mystified from scene one as Bale did his "hair" and never quit.  Whoever edited this film is a genius.  It moves, moves, moves and delights at every frame.  The top five actors came to work with a dedication you'll seldom see in Hollyweird these days...  "Hustle" is quirky, sad, glad, combative, full of betrayal, full of ruined dreams, double reverse double crosses and hoots at every turn.  Jennifer Lawrence is beyond sublime in her acting, looks and quirks in this drama.  One of the BEST movies of the last ten years, that's for sure.  I've heard a bunch of people bad-mouth this movie and say they don't "get it"...  Best they slide back to the comic book series and take a big breath and forget this masterpiece.  Bradley Cooper gets reinvented here.  Amy Adams is unreal from her split open dress to those cunning eyes.  The mayor - Jeremy Renner - is perfectly cast and gives a command performance.  But it's Bale who kills in this one.  Honest to god I did NOT know it was Bale until 3/4 of the way through the film and I hollered so loud my girlfriend thought I went insane!  His bald spots, his comb-over, his shyster Elvis glasses, his big belly, his stumbling ways, faltering heart - NEVER KNEW IT WAS HIM until it hit me like a lightning clap!  The dude is the new DeNiro - the new "Raging Bull"....  Casting was unreal and the director got every screaming ounce of talent out of this crew - the hottest actors working in Hollyweird today.  It's a movie you could watch twice a year and LOVE and then explain it to your film challenged friends.  And folks, that's the definition of a CLASSIC.

American Hustle is a comedy-drama of a crime genre that is loosely based on the FBI ABSCAM operation of the 1970's and 1980's. The story is about two con artists that were forced to work with an FBI agent to capture a sting operation.

During the 70's and the 80's,a ring of crooked deals were captured on video by the FBI at the backdrop of New Jersey. That led to almost a dozen arrests of U.S. senators, members of the U.S. House of Representatives and other politicians. Ambitious FBI agent Richie DiMaso forces the aid of the a con artists pair:Irving Rosenfeld, a small-time criminal who deals in stolen and faked art as well as fake loan scams; and his seductive British partner Sydney Prosser,who is also known as Lady Edith Greensly. The pair are forced to assist the FBI in nabbing other con artists and crooks in the area after being caught in one of his cons by DiMaso. When a chain of evidence mounts that leads towards corruption in the office of Mayor Carmine Polito, DiMaso concocts a scam that will ultimately bring down many politicians that includes Polito himself. Disgusted by their forced employment with DiMaso after he discovers mob ties that may ultimately lead to his own death,Irving and his partner make a ploy to begin a scheme of their own to get out from it. What makes matters worse is the fact that Irving's wife,Rosalyn tries desperately to retain Irving's affection and attention by constantly interfering with him.

This is definitely one of the best films during its year of release. The performances of Christian Bale,Amy Adams,Bradley Cooper and most especially Jennifer Lawrence are definitely great and memorable. They played their characters interestingly and passionately as they were able to switch from comedy to drama with ease. Also,they obviously researched their characters very well. No wonder that all of them were nominated for an Oscar. Added to that,the movie has lots of fun and energy as it was engaging from beginning to end. Added to that,the killer 70's soundtrack definitely made it enjoyable as well. Despite lacking intelligence and the unevenness of the story,the viewer will definitely get their money's worth with the heartwarming performances of the lead stars alone.

Quick story recap: A con artist, Christian Bale, meets his mate and match, Amy Adams, and together they do lots of jobs until they are busted in a sting operation.  They are forced to help the government bust bigger fish to get out of trouble.  Though everyone in  the movie are bad people doing bad things, I still liked them.  At times you need to have a suspension of belief at certain events which were put in there for dark humor while i realized those parts couldn't  be real in any reality I was entertained by them. The movie is however very loosely based on true events. I think the only true part being the means in which government operated it's sting operation in the 70s.

 I loved the acting. Christian Bale was great. Amy Adams was great. Jennifer Lawrence was great.

Overall, I was very entertained.  The dark humor with the mind games and the relationships between characters kept me into it until the end.

American Hustle is a fantastic movie, even though I really dislike actor Bradley Cooper (fortunately cast as a bad guy). Here's the breakdown: Most importantly, the writing is excellent. Add to that great acting and directing. And great filming. And a great sound track. All my own subjective opinions, I know. Just show me something original, fresh, CREATIVE (as opposed to commercial), and ENTERTAINING. So why so many negative reviews? Because when you do something creative and original, a lot of people just don't get it. Not enough special effects, explosions, or graphic violence for the typical jaded movie goer. American Hustle is the movie Quentin Tarantino would make if he wasn't psychotic.

American Hustle, loosely based on the late 1970s Abscam political scandal with a social story added to puff it up, is one of the greatest films of this era and easily the best film Hollywood has produced since No Country for Old Men. To recite the reasons why this film attains such Olympian levels would take a dissertation; I'll try to do it in a few paragraphs. -- Acting of the principal roles. To say American Hustle if full of stars is like saying 9/11 was a national disaster. The acting of the principal and supporting roles is universally insightful and credible, beginning with Christian Bale who turns in the best work of his career, full of subtlety and nuance yet laced with over-the-top emotions. He is equaled by the star-turn of Jennifer Lawrence, America's hottest actress who is undoubtedly this era's version of Barbara Stanwyck or Susan Hayward. Watch Hayward's Academy Award-winning performance in 1958's I Want To Live and convince yourself this isn't Lawrence playing that role. Her acting is at over often over the peak emotionally and lacks subtlety, but that will come with age and experience. At age 24, she is already among the greatest female stars and is destined for further greatness in the years to come. Amy Adams, one of the best supporting actresses in Hollywood, also is the best here she's ever been, expanding her resume with a sexual performance far from the buttoned down roles of Doubt,Julie & Julia and elsewhere. Bradley Cooper, who helped fund the film, is far more effective than in his last film with many of these actors, Silver Linings Playbook, as are the supporting actors from Jeremy Renner as Carmine Polito down to Robert DeNiro appearing unbilled. Few films with such star power achieve anywhere near the orgiastic heights of American Hustle. -- Universally wonderful and credible acting is always a result of direction, so equal marks to director Mark Russell. -- Next on my list is the camerawork that captures every actor in extreme close-up at one time or another, revealing their humanity and transcending what could have been cardboard cut-outs instead of flesh and blood people. Watch Jennifer Lawrence's make-up when Pete Musane (Jack Huston) wipes away her tears after her confrontation with husband Bale when she reveals to the mob what's really going on. Or stay tuned for Bale's carefully nuanced sideways glances throughout, always caught in close up. Remarkable camerawork throughout is among the most distinguishing landmark's of this awesome movie. -- A script, partially based in reality, that moves at laser speed, rarely giving you a chance to catch your breath, while also telling a compelling story about greed, incompetence, lust, family life, loyalty and the sidebar we love to see on the screen these days, the Mafia. Never does this script let us down, whether it's telling the story of Abscam, the real-life political scandal of the 1970s, or the made up story about a scammer-art dealer-laundry owner and his complicated relationships with a family, girlfriend, loan marks, the FBI and all the other slime that comes into contact with his life. The script gets an A-plus and is nearly as good as the Coen's Western metaphor, No Country for Old Men. -- Danny Elfman's musical score, featuring lots of real-life 1970s hits and even an occasional hit from the 1960s -- White Rabbit is from 1967 -- endorses the period and its excesses to a capital T. -- Production values and editing makes a film with lots of drama and negative content into a joy to watch from the opening to closing scenes. Instead of being repelled at the shenanigans of these hucksters and their ties to organized (and disorganized) crime, we revel in joy from scene to scene watching these characters in our voyeuristic pattern of living a second life as a bystander to the history being portrayed on the screen. -- Art direction, costume design, look and feel. Compare this movie, which accurately depicts the late disco era, to the failure in art design, costuming, hair and makeup of The Last Days Of Disco, a 1990s fantasy about 1979, to see how this aspect of filmmaking can make the difference between a movie of greatness and one of mediocrity. I watch 30 movies a month and rarely do I see one where all the elements come together so well to create such a wonderful atmosphere of entertainment. American Hustle is sure to be watched as long as people watch movies and can take its place in the pantheon of social misfit-crime dramas that began with The Godfather and have carried into modern times through the likes of Goodfellas,Casino,Kill the Irishman and No Country for Old Men. If it isn't clear by now, I heartily endorse your purchase, rental, download or theft of American Hustle. Having seen this film about a dozen times, I would now say it is the best film I have seen in the 21st century, besting the two others I know that tower above all others -- The Pianist and No Country For Old Men.

A film with 10 Academy Award nominations gives we movie fans the idea that a particular film might just have something extraordinary to offer.  This time the idea makes perfect sense.  Do you want to see a movie that combines outstanding acting, tight direction and a deft, clever and believable script?  You have found the movie of the week, and perhaps the movie of the year.  Stay tuned for the Oscar awards.
 The ensemble cast of Christian Bale, Amy Adams, Bradley Cooper and Jennifer Lawrence received the rare accolade of nominations-in order-for best actor, best actress, best supporting actor and best supporting actress.  Can you name a film in which the cast got the nod for all four major acting awards?  (Answer below)  A careful look at each individual performance reveals that the cast well deserves each and every nomination.  Lawrence, at age 23, now has three nominations and thus far one win to her credit.  Amazing.  Bale is nearly unrecognizable, so thoroughly has he transformed his visual self.  Amy Adams shuns her nice girl next door image fine tuned in Trouble with the Curve and turns herself into a brilliant, very sexy con artist.  Cooper plays a driven, ambitious, over reaching FBI agent so well that we are disgusted, appalled and intrigued by his character.
 David O. Russell (who wrote and directed last years superb Silver Linings Playbook-also with Cooper and Lawrence and for which Lawrence received the Academy Award for Best Actress- and also wrote and directed the Gulf War film Three Kings) both wrote and directed American Hustle.  The film is loosely modeled on the ABSCAM sting operation that in the end netted several congressmen, a mayor and a senator in New Jersey.  Try to imagine how brilliant a writer must be to fashion a moving love story worked around an FBI sting.  Russell got nominations for best director and for best original screenplay.  Sharing the writing credits is Eric Warren Singer who also scripted the medium warm thriller The International.
 The film overall, which I found completely satisfying and give four enthusiastic saw blades, received the nomination for best picture.
 American Hustle cost a modest $40 million to make but has already raked in over four times that amount at the box office.  When we viewers justly reward for excellence, my heart leaps.  It encourages others to produce wonderful films for us to watch. "American Hustle" is brilliant! This is how the story goes: Brilliant con man Irving Rosenfeld, along with his equally cunning and seductive British partner Sydney Prosser, is forced to work for a wild FBI agent named Richie DiMaso. DiMaso pushes them into a world of Jersey power-brokers and mafia that's as dangerous as it is enchanting. Carmine Polito is the passionate, volatile, New Jersey political operator caught between the con-artists and Feds. Irving's unpredictable wife Rosalyn could be the one to pull the thread that brings the entire world crashing down.

The cast led by Christian Bale (in another terrific performance as Irving Rosenfeld), Bradley Cooper (just as impressive as Richie DiMaso, also executive produced the film), Amy Adams (superb as Sydney Prosser), Jeremy Renner (excellent as Carmine Polito) & Jennifer Lawrence (in another impressive and terrific performance as Rosalyn Rosenfeld) is brilliant. The directing by David O. Russell (also wrote the story & screenplay) is brilliant. The story & screenplay by Russell & Eric Warren Singer (also executive produced the film) is brilliant.

The music by Danny Elfman is brilliant. The cinematography by Linus Sandgren is brilliant. The film editing by Alan Baumgarten, Jay Cassidy & Crispin Struthers is brilliant. The casting by Lindsay Graham & Mary Vernieu is brilliant. The production design by Judy Becker is brilliant. The art direction by Jesse Rosenthal is brilliant. The set decoration by Heather Loeffler, set dressings by Christopher Analoro, Chris Centola, Deborah Kehs, Adam Roffman & Jeffrey Schneider is brilliant. The costume design by Michael Wilkinson is brilliant. The prosthetic make-up effects by Wesley Wofford are brilliant. The special effects coordinated by John Ruggieri is brilliant. The visual effects coordinated by Ryan Suchor & Liz Vogtsberger, supervised by Sean Devereaux, Tim LeDoux, Marc D. Rienzo, Edson Williams & Danny Yoon is brilliant. The stunts coordinated by Ben Bray & Frank Torres is brilliant.

This is a brilliant and well-crafted film that is entertaining and intriguing, as well as interesting. David O. Russell directs another brilliant and impressive film to add his resume. Christian Bale, Bradley Cooper, Amy Adams, Jeremy Renner & Jennifer Lawrence give impressive performances and also impressively lead a brilliant cast, as well. This was one of the best movies of the last winter season and was also one of the best movies of last year (an awards contender, on top of it), as well.

There is very little that I can add to 1500+ reviews of American Hustle, but I can add a few points that should be kept in mind.

a) The fact that the film garnered no Academy Awards points to the fact that genre-bending, ensemble-cast films with a fresh voice and a fresh look have difficulty competing with more traditional films.

b) The film is very, very long.  Silver Linings Playbook, e.g., is far less ambitious as a film, but it is tighter and, with all its quirkiness, far more conventional.

c) The score is sensational and it works very well with the narrative arcs of the film.  Jeff Lynne, Steely Dan, Chicago, Duke Ellington,  Ella Fitzgerald, et al. may simply not be sufficiently chic for contemporary Academy voters, despite their magic.

d) The hair, makeup, and costuming are stunning.  The slightly-over-the-top 70s look is done to perfection.

e)  While the overall plot arcs eventually result in something magical, this is a movie that consists of brilliant scenes.  While the dialogue is sometimes a bit literary it is no less magical.

f) The individual performances are uniformly stellar and even with its massive ambitions they manage to add up to more than the sum of their parts, despite the fact that the film is very long and a little creaky in the joints.

g)  The cast and crew deserve our appreciation for attempting to do something quirky on the grand scale.  We need fresh, imaginative filmmaking that shatters the categories and breaks the molds.  This is not a perfect movie but it is a superb bit of entertainment.

h)  Dont miss it, but allow lots of time to absorb and enjoy it.

The lavish praise for this film gets turned on by scenes & features that are adolescent and pre-adult, beginning with the opening five minutes of Bale fussing with his comb over. Critics can't resist praising this, whereas my reaction (not having read any reviews) was that better planning could deliver this message about Bale (or the universe?) in a far more economical fashion.  That it doesn't, bodes bad for the film and suggests the film is going to be incoherent and reckless, a verdict that is quickly confirmed.  The opening 30" of dialogue was a hodge-podge and Sydney's character (played by Amy Adams) then went every which way, and having her bob around histrionically adds to the film's incoherence.  Which man was she after?  What qualities was she looking for?  Was she mad?  A scene that represents the manic ugliness of the entire film for me is the toilet stall scene, where Cooper and Adams veer toward copulation in the tiny stall.  Why in the the world was this particular scene devised and thrust upon us?  Answer: this is the primitivism the director is good at scattering about and droves of people love it.  It's a trademark capsule of a wild, chaotic and quirky pattern devoid of maturity that critics have termed "thrilling".

What follows are adoring excerpts gathered from newspaper reviews on imdb.  Except for a few brackets in the form of [ ], what follows is critics' praise in their own words.  It's clear what they dote on: intensity and unending sensation. I see their terms of reference as on a collision course with cinema as we know it from LOLITA,  GIRL WITH THE PEARL EARRING,  PAN'S LABYRINTH,  LOURDES (with Sylvie Testud) + the calm, poised, thought provoking treatment of life and its mysteries in MUD (unfortunate title) and other films that'd now be jeered at --- as too staid, slow or not spastic enough --- not to mention too lacking in a steady stream of obscenities.

Here's the first adoring excerpt.  In this excerpt and those to follow, note the qualities that send the critics into ga-ga land.

"Its great -but then again, was a film that features Jennifer Lawrence over-zealously cleaning to the strains of Live and Let Die ever going to be anything other than great?"  [Can the critic actually MEAN this???]

"Each of the main characters are their own individual wells of entertainment, with their plethora of bizarre ticks.  Whilst it occasionally feels muddled from the sheer wealth of characters, the off the wall intensities and surprises are thrilling."

"He takes four entirely preposterous characters, who take themselves entirely seriously: they begin to enact something like a dysfunctional four-way comedy routine, or perhaps a challengingly atonal modern jazz quartet. They are people who hate and love each other, and everyone often seems on the point of screaming .  .  .  .  ". [A key to the film's popularity?]

"The pressure-cooker simmer of suppressed madness bubbles continuously through American Hustle .  .  .  .  ."

"The bizarre, uproarious and semi-credible story rattles along with plenty of comic setpieces along the way. Richie is infuriated by his tightass boss Stoddard Thorsen, played by Louis CK, who is reluctant to use official funds for his crazy entrapment schemes and keeps on telling him a homely anecdote about his childhood ice fishing, which Richie keeps petulantly interrupting when he thinks he understands the moral. It is a running gag, punctuated by furious rows and there is even a psychotic flashback in which the two appear to be pulling guns on each other in some scuzzy bathroom: did that really happen? Or just in Richie's head?"  [Many critics swallowed this cunning bait and were diverted by this nit wit running gag and had to describe it at length.]

"The performances are far from subtle, yet they have an eye-popping, beads -of-sweat commitment."  [ Exactly --- INTENSITY trumps all else..  "Far from subtle".  "Eye-popping, beads of sweat [performances]."  Yes, this critic has nailed it.  It's another way of saying INTENSITY, via mini- shocks from the roller coaster taking curves abruptly, jerkily and in "shake em up" fashion.  Lace heavily with extreme emotional states, circumstances pushed to the limit, profanity & cleavages and you have a winning formula for one and all.  Well, for a great number, anyway.

I so much prefer recent films that are calm and collected:  THANK YOU FOR SMOKING,  AN EDUCATION,  BURN AFTER READING,  and (yes!) MUD.  I feel vulgarized and knocked around by this film.

Unlike its predecessor Silver Linings Playbook, American Hustle is a slow-cooking picture. It takes a long time to get going, and doesnt really explain where were going, but once we start rolling it becomes a cinematic dream.

The exposition, weirdly, is the film at some of its clunkiest. Maybe its the gradual, deliberate pacing or the oddly deafening silence (we don't get the stellar soundtrack til about halfway through), but something about it feels uninvolving. The con scheme set up by Irving and Sydney (later Edith) doesnt really make sense, and this disconnect makes it hard to stay interested and engaged with whats going down.

The intervention of FBI Agent Richie DiMaso, played to perfection by Bradley Cooper (who, in just two films, has become one of my favorite contemporary actors), is the first great curveball thrown at the lead duo. They get caught for their scheme and, in a similarly selfish fashion, he bets the odds in his favor and pushes them to topple greater and greater idols, not for Justice but for his own reputation.

The film is often patchy, alternating between sequences of nap-worthy doldrums and truly fantastic filmmaking. My favorite moments are the soundtrack-heavy ones, such as the disco nightclub scene (one of the best Ive ever seen) and the montage of arrests at the films climax. Its extraordinary how the glorious 70s soundtrack really raises the impact from watching a dime-a-dozen crime caper to this sublime, awe-inspiring cinematic experience. Its like watching the greatest music video that was never made.

Other highlights, it goes without saying, are those featuring the unforgettable Jennifer Lawrence.  She plays the classic, genre-perfect crazy New Jersey wife with a bitchy honesty that never feels over-the-top or flamboyant. She exercises such remarkable control yet leaves a lasting screen presence, its hard to remember she is in the movie so little compared to the other main characters.

This films greatest strength, though, is in its unique brand of messaging. The Wolf of Wall Street (which I actually prefer) does have some line between right and wrong, even if that line is dotted and hard-to-read, American Hustle has no such line at all. Who of any of these characters, is good? Who is wholly unselfish? I love to see this kind of challenging storytelling, where there is no one really doing the right thing, and everyone is working an angle. Hollywood is often too timid to make a movie as cynical as this, and I applaud David O. Russell for having the guts to.

While it has some narrative issues and clunks along at times, it is an often-entertaining movie that delivers some unforgettable movie moments. Love it or hate it, people will be talking about American Hustle for years to come.

Fantastic performances!  Interesting, flawed characters.  Plot twists and surprises.  Realistic drama.  Believable comedy.  This movie is incredibly different.  Supposedly, a lot of the scenes were improvised!  Keep that in mind and this film is fascinating.

BUT . . . some of you will HATE it.  Why?  Well, let's be honest: this movie moves at a steady, turtle's pace with much of the entertainment coming from the character interaction.  If you do NOT like watching the subtle back and forth between characters, the exchange of meaningful glances, thoughtful dialogue, or scenes without urgency, do NOT see this film.

It is a character-driven hybrid that reminds me of Goodfellas at times, Casino at times, the Usual Suspects at times, etc.

American Hustle is its own theatrical beast, though.  Thoughtful, mysterious, tense, and funny!  To merge all of those qualities successfully is a BIG accomplishment.

You can relate to every character.  The cast is incredible--not just the stars on the cover.  You are going to see a lot of talent in this film.

Watch for a breakout, subtly hilarious performance by Louis C.K.  And, no matter what you do, rent it for the first scene during which Bale's character fixes his hair and another character intervenes soon after.  Hilarious.  :)

Ok. Yes, this is the third film in a row that I've reviewed that was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Picture. It's just that I've been having a marathon of some sort. Also of note is that the date this review is published befalls my birthday. Happy Birthday to Me! Even though I'm writing this a month or so in advance, it's still nice to write. 'American Hustle' was one of those Academy Award Best Picture nominees I most wanted to view myself. I'll be honest when I say that back in August 2013 when the first trailer for the film came out, I was not interested at all. And then later on I watched the second trailer and started to get interested. It's the costumes and cast that really got me attached. It looked like a film that puts you in the 70's and I'm glad to note it does. Now let's read my review of 'American Hustle'.

'American Hustle' follows Irving Rosenfeld (Played by Christian Bale) a businessman who operates a small business of dry-cleaning shops. But Irving's greatest business success was as a con man operating a fake money lending scheme, to fool people into handing him 5,000 dollars for credits. He has a wife and child as well. After meeting and falling in love with Sydney Prosser (Played by Amy Adams), a big dreaming, smart girl, Irving asks her to join him in his operation. But the two are soon busted by senile and aggressive FBI agent Richard DiMaso (Played by Bradley Cooper) who forces the two to con the Mayor Carmine Polito (Played by Jeremy Renner) or face jail time. But things go too far with the two whining up attracting the attention of the mob.

'American Hustle' is a very interesting film. But the most interesting thing is the characters. Some of them start out cool and end up being a steam pot. The characters are relatable and well fleshed out throughout the bloated 2 hours and 10 minutes runtime. Usually when you watch a movie, the characters are more of a side dish, with the action the main course, and it hurts the film in many ways. But this is obviously not the case with this film. We are given emotionally acceptable characters, characters you hate, characters you love. Highly realistic characters with motives for their actions and interesting back stories. We feel their desperation and anger and fear.

Director 'David O. Russell' dives into this crime cape masterfully. Coming off the critical successes of 'Silver Lining Playbook' and 'The Fighter' O. Russell get's inside the story, delivering ripe camerawork and giving us hearty characters, characters that we connect with solely because of O. Russell's direction.

But I feel the film lagged in the third act before finally coming to a close. The film feels like 3 hours rather than 2. It includes loads of excess that would have served the film better if it had been cut and left on the cutting room floor. I suggest removing a few nice but rather un-necessary scenes involving DiMaso and his boss (Played by Louis C.K) as well as a scene involving DiMaso at his home, which I felt did nothing to progress the story in anyway. O. Russell is a director who is overly talented but can't seem to leave anything out.

The cast is what really makes this film glimmer. 'Christian Bale' coming off the success of the Batman Trilogy plays Irving. He performs the anger, confusion, and smarts that came with the character. He was able to move the story along. 'Amy Adams' shines as Sydney. Her fake British accent is perfect and her performance is remarkably convincing as the clever and decidedly beautiful woman. 'Bradley Cooper' surprisingly pulls off the dramatic role as the somewhat senile detective. I have to give him a tip of the hat, when I say he really puts some effort into the role, and overshadows Bale in the shots they share together. 'Jeremy Renner' plays the sweet mayor, and really pulls off the powerful and very much likable character he plays. I felt sorry for him at the end and felt Renner made the best of his screentime. Also during the end we get a very surprising (and delighting) uncredited cameo from 'Robert De'Niro' as a very powerful mob boss, who plays the tension high and convincing, and gave me a small smirk every time I saw him on screen.

The costumes and hair styling is also pretty elegant. Sydney's curly hair is pretty fashionable to the period, and her flashy and scandalous clothing is quite beautiful to look at. Irving himself sports a nice hairdo, as does the agent, DiMaso in a short cut curly hairdo as well. The costumes were well selected and fit the period well. The hairdos were well done and also fit the period well and look really cool as well.

All and All 'American Hustle' is a smart film with top notch performances, solid characters, great directing, and even if the film is a bit too long, it's still entertaining. B- 4/7/14

'American Hustle' is rated R for pervasive language, some sexual content and brief violence. It's appropriate for ages 14 and up.

A lot of talent working hard in this movie, but only with sporadic success.  One of the biggest names, Robert De Niro, has an uncredited cameo, and unkind though it might be to say, I think his decision to keep his name off the credits was a wise one.  The problem is with the rhythm and direction -- there are scenes that seem either unnecessary or to go on to long.  For example, the scene with the agents who believe that they have just taped an incriminating phone call is probably not needed, but certainly goes on far too long.  The scene with Richie (Bradley Cooper) and Sydney (Amy Adams) in the bathroom stall adds nothing to our grasp of these characters or to the plot.  The running gag of Richie's boss (Louis C. K.) and the ice-fishing story is weak and unnecessary  The big party scene involving the sheikh and the mobsters -- way too long.  Carmen Polito, mayor of Camden, NJ, goes on and on about how his constituents are his family, long after we get it.  The energy of the actors and the excellent production values aren't enough to save these scenes, and they throw the rhythm out of kilter.

George Roy Hill's "The Sting" ran like clockwork -- like the sting itself.  This is a sort of sting movie, and (thanks to Rosalyn [Jennifer Lawrence], the wife of con-man Irving Rosenfeld [Christian Bale]) the sting DOESN'T run like clockwork -- but the movie should, and it doesn't.  The con artists, Irving and Sydney, are constantly having to adapt to unforeseen circumstances -- and there is a possibility of humor in that -- but the adjustments aren't always as funny as they could be.  There is a certain satisfaction in the ending's showing that folks who have to con for a living are better at it than the government, but I'm not sure that that makes up for the dull patches on the way.  I think that Cooper, Adams, Lawrence, and Bale -- as well as Jeremy Renner, who plays Carmine Polito -- are fine, and some local scenes work well enough, but not enough of them.

Viewers shouldn't expect a satire on the level of "M.A.S.H." or "Network."  Despite the title "American Hustle" it's not clear that there's anything specifically American in the targets of such satire as there is beyond the setting.  Somewhere in the background, and signaled early, there's a point being made about self-invention and re-invention (this is, I think, what all the stuff about everybody's hair is all about), but it hardly deserves the name of cultural criticism.  Further, the cartoonishness of the characterization distances us from the characters' predicaments, but they are not reduced to social or culturally recognizable types in a way that would enable us to say confidently that this or that aspect of the culture is being satirized.

So what's to like?  The energy of the acting is engaging; De Niro's brief moment is gripping and well-paced; there's a great late 1970's soundtrack, and the '70's look is faithfully recreated -- but these alone didn't redeem the movie as a whole for me.  So . . . it's OK, but a bit tiresome, I'm afraid.

Loosely based on the Abscam incident, this is a must-see movie for everyone who wants to believe we still can make movies the old-fashioned way and that leading men and women can step into any part and make you believe who they are. Good good great film.

This fictionalized true story isn't the disco-flavored Ocean's 11 remake the trailers made it out to be. Its main selling point is that it allows Amy Adams to finally be a sultry vixen, but the garish '70s fashions take your mind off that pretty quickly, such as how it opens with Christian Bale spending several minutes putting together one hideous and complex comb-over. Jennifer Lawrence's tall blonde Snookie routine definitely should've gotten her a third Oscar because it takes great skill to be that deliberately horrendous, and her vaunted kiss with Amy is more Bugs-Bunny-kissing-Elmer-Fudd psychological warfare than anything remotely erotic. Plus I was taken out of the moment during a scene in the mayor's office because the window shows a New England building I've both driven past several hundred times and even briefly worked in. Make it a rental or a cable viewing rather than a purchase.

Sure, "12 Years a Slave" won the Oscar, but "American Hustle" was far and away the best movie of 2013.  Some say it's a slow burn.  Fair enough, but any payoff from any movie deserves some time to bake, otherwise every movie would just be all action flicks.  Amy Adams was robbed, as she gave the performance of the year and of her career (and that's saying A LOT based on her resume).  Cooper, Bale, Lawrence... all in top-notch performances.  But, aside from Adams, the one who stole the show was Jeremy Renner.  In a movie full of low-life scoundrels, Renner's character was the only person you didn't resent at any point.  If you're a fan of 70's political dramas then this one is for you.  Highly re-watchable.
