I swear that's all I could think of during this movie.  He's doing a Robert DeNiro impression.  Then when Robert DeNiro does a cameo later in the movie, that's really when it got weird.

I watched this one twice, I think mainly because it kind of lost me in the middle somewhere and I wanted to be sure I didn't miss anything.  The movie is good.  She said tentatively.  It is good, it's just kind of hard to stick with.  Both times I watched it, I got up and went to the kitchen to clean, so I'm not sure if it just lost me or what.

Two things that stick out most, forgive me on this, Amy Adams cleavage....ha ha ha, AND Jennifer Lawrence's performance.  What was the deal with Amy Adams costumes?  Every outfit was cut to her navel.  I kept thinking something was going to fly out.  Now I was a kid in the 70s so I was around and I do not recall everyone wearing outfits with their boobs hanging out.  Very distracting although I guess that was for the guys.

Jennifer Lawrence, wow! She was simply amazing to me.  You know I thought of her as this Hunger Games, "Potteresque" kind of actress.  I saw her in the movie she won the Oscar for and I thought she was good.  I saw Hunger Games and wasn't impressed.  But she nails this character.  I felt like I've known people like that and I was just floored by that performance.  She is worth watching the film for, now she doesn't come in for a while, but wait for it.  So worth it.

This movie is supposed to be funny.  It is, kind of, but don't expect a lot of bellyaches from laughing.  Overall, it's worth the price for the video.  I remembered the Abscam debacle but didn't understand it at the time.  This helps get a better understanding of it. The cast, the script, the music...all perfection! Kudos to the director for capturing a place and time impeccably! Absolutely superb!

True chemistry between Christian Bale and Amy Adams; my favorite part was the two of them in the car after Irving gets his head handed to him by Mayor Polito for screwing him.  Well thought out "deception" screenplay!

The director missed the mark. It seemed he was more interested in boob shots than what might pass as good camera angles.
Kept watching hoping it would get better. Finally, after 45 minutes or so we had to turn it off. Awards?
The acting is excellent.  The story plot is drawn out.  If you are bored it is worth the evening watch.

Excellent writing if this was a novel, I would put this up with the rest of the great works of literature. There is a lot of depth to this film and phenomenal acting from this bunch, as always. I skipped over some of the more vulgar/graphic moments, cause it's not my thing (and I wouldn't have minded less swearing), but overall, I was very impressed by the film. The story, the irony, emotion felt toward the characters yes and yes.

I love mostly anything that Christian Bale is in, but I'm still on the fence about Amy Adams. However, she did a great job in this movie as well as Bradley Cooper, Jeremy Renner, and Jennifer Lawrence. I thought the story was engaging and kept me interested the whole time. I enjoyed the 70s scenery, styling, and soundtrack! Living close to Atlantic City, it was interesting to hear a story about its beginnings. There were a very sexy scenes as well as some language, but otherwise it was pretty clean. I would recommend it to people who enjoy an engaging story.

This movie is a hoot.  This is the modern day version of "The Sting" with Paul Newman.

The acting is superb.  The story line is engrossing.  The plot twists are interesting and effective.  Pay attention so you don't miss anything.

It's a riot of a ride.  You'll want to watch it again just to see if you missed anything and you'll enjoy it every bit as much the second, third or tenth time you watch it.

I was taken aback when "American Hustle" was awarded the Golden Globe for best comic picture.  If one finds greed, ambition, and corruption funny instead of tragic I guess you could call this film funny.  Personally I found it all a little ironic.  For those too young to remember events similar to what are depicted in this film  did happen.  If you find that incredible well this was the Carter Administration.  Director-writer David O. Russell expertly captures the sense of time of place from the attitudes, the music, and the fashions.  Stylistically the film is very reminiscent of Scorsese but Russell adds enough of his own flourishes to distinguish it from copycat status.  The ensemble cast assembled here is impeccable with standouts being Jeremy Renner as an entrapped New Jersey mayor and Jennifer Lawrence as a ditzy housewife.  I give Amy Adams' bad British accent the pass because her character is in fact an American stripper.  Robert De Niro has a scene-stealing cameo as a multilingual mobster.  The hair department should have gotten an Oscar for Christian Bale's hairpiece and Bradley Cooper's mini curlers.  The scene with Lawrence and the microwave oven is one for the ages.  I went into this film with heightened expectations and they were met but not surpassed.

{3.5 stars}

AMERICAN HUSTLE is a whimsical social satire on greed and the amoral rat & mouse game of FBI/governmental entrapment, with a lot of insightful stuff about the world of appearances, selfish human agendas, and the phoniness in general behind them all. Set in the late 1970s, it captures (and ridicules) that era very well, especially with its use of 70s theme music for specific scenes.

While AMERICAN HUSTLE kept my attention throughout its two-plus-hour length, it may move a little too slowly for some tastes and could definitely use more hard tension. Much of the persistent humor is of the smirk-guffaw variety. There are also frequent attempts at lol-slapstick, but the exploding microwaves and one guy beating another over the head with a telephone just aren't particularly funny. This film would probably have worked better if it had just stuck to dry satirical humor, keeping the one hilarious exception of the impromptu after-the-big-bust party by the feds. Anyway, there are some twisty surprises here and there, not all of which are very believable, and it ties up a bit too easily at the end. Though AMERICAN HUSTLE works well as light but meaningful entertainment, the fact that it just doesn't go as far and deep as it could have keeps it from being the rip-roaring success it might have been. Better plotting, more suspense, and sharper surprise elements could have won that Oscar.

All the same, Christian Bale (as not-so-bad-a-guy con artist Irving Rosenfeld), Amy Adams (as Rosenfeld's indispensable cohort Sydney Prosser), and Bradley Cooper (as self-serving FBI agent Richie DiMaso) give some nice performances here, with special kudos going to Jeremy Renner as Mayor/FBI target Carmine Polito.

American Hustle is an excellent and entertaining Comedy/Crime Drama that combines great direction,a terrific cast,a wonderful script and a fantastic soundtrack all of those elements make American Hustle a great film that has to be seen.

Set in New York City in the late 1970s,American Hustle tells the story of two con artists,Irving Rosenfield(Christian Bale)and Sydney Prosser(Amy Adams)who have been forced by FBI agent Richie DiMasso(Bradley Cooper)to participate in a FBI operation called ABSCAM,a sting operation to set up corrupt politicians including Camden,New Jersey Mayor Carmine Polito(Jeremy Renner)and gangsters. As the stakes become higher and with danger coming at every corner Irving and Sydney have to figure out how to get out and survive.

Throughout the history of cinema,con artists and Grifters have been covered in movies ranging from The Sting(1973),The Grifters(1990)and now American Hustle,an amazing film from beginning to end that keep your attention with fantastic movie making that never stops. Right from it's weird and offbeat opening American Hustle is a movie that combines Comedy,Crime Drama and a true life tale that is funny and quirky and at other times serious and intense giving viewers a movie that plays by it's own rules and creates it's own world. With American Hustle David O'Russell gives us a movie that is dazzling bringing viewers into the crime world of the 1970s showing the personal and professional lives of con artists,federal agents,politicians and gangsters never knowing where the story or it's characters will go and even though AH is a fact based story the movie is not too dark. When you look at AH you will see that the movie was obviously influenced in many ways by Martin Scorsese's classic Gangster epics such as Goodfellas(1990)and Casino(1995)with the way the camera moves,the style and look of the film and the use of narration replacing Gangsters and Mobsters with con artists but O'Russell takes the style and makes it his own. The Comedy in AH is great and hilarious because the laughs are never forced on viewers or telling them when scenes are funny but lets the viewers figure out when scenes are funny whether it's in some of the scenes or in the main characters dialog or actions. The Comedy is balanced out by the Crime Drama elements as well which are done with attention and detail like a other Crime Dramas and you are gripped with every scene that involves cops and crime. But the Crime Drama element isn't always serious and is entertaining. The beautiful photography by Linus Sandgren and amazing production design by Judy Becker truly add to the film and give AH a realistic look and feel of the 1970s with vibrant colors and sets that pull you into the world that AH wants to portray and it's one of the reasons the movie succeeds. The main characters in the film whether it's the con artists,federal agents are fascinating and interesting with laughs and depth because with each main character everyone wants to succeed at what they do whether it's good or bad. Also,with the characters there is no black and white but a gray area that is complex and real and you will relate to some of the characters in some ways. The screenplay by Eric Singer and David O'Russell is impressive and well-done with dialog that is a mixture of funny and serious. The ending of American Hustle is wonderful,surprising and unexpected and fits with films about con artists and Grifters. An outstanding conclusion to a great movie.

The whole cast is amazing. Christian Bale is excellent and at his best as Irving Rosenfield,with Bale bringing intensity and emotional(and physical)depth to the role. Bradley Cooper is brilliant and funny as FBI agent Richie DiMasso,with Copper being offbeat and dramatic. Amy Adams is terrific and beautiful as Sydney Prosser,Irving's partner in crime and has great scenes with Bale,Cooper and Lawrence. Jeremy Renner is outstanding as Mayor Carmine Polito,a New Jersey politician. Jennifer Lawrence is amazing and sexy as Roselyn Rosenfield,Irving's attractive but overbearing wife. Also,lookout for a great uncredited appearance from Robert De Niro in a great performance as Victor Tellegio,a high level gangster. Louis C.K(Stoddard Thorsen),Jack Huston(Pete Musane),Michael Pena(Paco Hernandez),Shea Whigham(Carl),Alessandro Nivola(Anthony Amando)and Paul Hermane(Alfonse Simone)give good performances as well.

The direction by David O'Russell is brilliant and stylish,with O'Russell always moving the camera with tracking shots,close-ups and a nice visual style. Terrific direction,O'Russell.

The score Danny Elfman isn't always used but good when it's heard. The film has a great soundtrack with songs by Elton John(Goodbye Yellow Brick Road),Wings(Live And Let Die),The Temptations(Papa Was A Rolling Stone),Duke Ellington(Jeep's Blues)and more. Outstanding soundtrack.

Yes, I understand he gained all this weight for the role and had to wear a bad hair piece but geez his look was just so yucky. But hey, I see why he was nominated because he seemed to really embody this con artist character for sure. I also hated how you could see that the makeup artists or whatever did not do his "baldness" right. On both Christian and Robert DeNiro you could tell that it was fake!! What ticks me off is that the movie trailer and all the award nominations (and actual awards) for this movie made it appear as the greatest movie in years. And of course like an idiot, I purchased the Blu-ray without first seeing it...which I rarely do by the way...and now I am out of $25 for a silly movie that will just gather dust in my movie cabinet. I am also surprised that this film is directed by David O. Russell. Comparing his other great films to this one makes you wonder what happened. I give this 2 stars because the music was good and again for me Jennifer Lawrence is such a great actress -- I just instantly felt that the whole tone of the movie changed once she came onscreen. Anyway, save your money and wait for this to come on cable or better yet just never watch it. You won't be missing anything...trust me!!

This movie begins with the statement that 'The story is partially based on facts'. It is a fictionalized version of the Abscam case dating to 1980 in which the FBI and the rest of the Justice Department arrange a sting operation to trap a NJ senator and seven congressmen and other Jersey pols into accepting bribes to get a license for a gambling casino in Atlantic City. We are introduced to the con artists (Christian Bales & Amy Adams) assisting each other in selling fake art masterpieces to gullible citizens including the FBI (a separate sting) who have something on Adams and keep her in a bare room for three days in order to get her to get Bales to participate in the great sting. The FBI agent behind the sting, Bradley Cooper, is also a con man chasing Adams and conning his boss to get taxpayer money to set up the sting. An agent is dressed as an Arab prince who offers money through Bales to various pols starting with the Majority Leader of the NJ House, Jeremy Renner, who is portrayed as a 'good guy' only interested in supporting his community through casino-generated income, and, less clearly, Congressmen and Senators. But Renner takes money and serves his time in prison as did all the other pols.
But why was a two-bit con man able to carry out such a sting? The movie suggests that it was greed on the part of the pols. This was emphasized by a cameo scene with Robert DeNiro playing a Mafia don who was offered a bribe and spoke Arabic to the agent playing the Arab prince who didn't understand him and couldn't answer in his presumed native tongue. All the pols in this scene should have recognized the sting but didn't.
Two problems with the plot were the need to 'torture' Adams to get Bales to cooperate and the ending was somewhat unclear. The rumor was that the NYTimes was about to break the case, that someone had leaked information to the paper, and the sting had to be completed fast by getting an admission of bribe acceptance from a lawyer who represented whom? Nevertheless, the film ends with the principals living happily ever after and those stung paying their expected debt to society.

I just watched "The Wolf of Wall Street" (TWOWS) -- a film that clocks in at just shy of three hours -- and then I watched "American Hustle" (AH) -- a film that clocks in at a little over two hours.  Guess which film seemed to have the longer running time to me?

TWOWS runs at an incredibly frenetic pace, mostly due to the standard terrific performance by Leonardo DiCaprio.  Sure, after watching that other film, you might look at your watch and think, "Wow!  Where did the day go!" but it is such a fun ride that you really don't care.  On the other hand, AH just seems to crawl along at a snail's pace, and after awhile I just wanted to roll up into a ball and go into my shell.

I will say that Christian Bale is fantastic, however.  When is he not?  I watched a bit of "The Machinist" the other night -- I've seen it in its entirety before, and I just wanted to see him in that film again to see if he was as good as I'd remembered -- and he might have even been better there, although it is a very close call.  He is such a versatile actor that he can move like a chameleon from one role to another and you might only recognize him after glancing at the credits.  The rest of the cast here is fine, of course, but it just seemed to me that this film is less than the sum of its parts; take each of the actors and he or she is very good to great, but add them together and something seems to be missing.

But to be fair, I will admit that I've never much been a fan of scam/caper flicks in general.  Usually, these types of films tend to believe that they are funnier than they are, and this one seems to follow suit.  I did get a chuckle or two here or there, but not as many as you'd think.

Well, if you are going to watch both AH and TWOWS, I'd recommend watching this one first.  Maybe I'd feel differently myself if I had.  I will round down from a 3.5 today on a minor disappointment for me.
Worst movie I saw in a while! Kept falling asleep repeatedly. Over and over again and again. Do not waste your time.

I'll keep this review short:  American Hustle should have won best picture.  Let me take it a step further: Christian Bale should have won best actor.  Yes, Matthew McConaughey is brilliant in Dallas Buyers Club, but Bale is better in American Hustle.  For that matter, Jennifer Lawrence should have won Best Supporting Actress for her role in American Hustle.

Best, most entertaining, movie I have seen in years.  Such a clever story with such clever editing.  The ensemble cast of actors is superb, each in his/her own way and style.  David O. Russell is a genius director.  I have now watched it seven times.  Each viewing discloses new treats and touches and nuances.  Clever! Clever!  A crying shame that it did not win a single Academy Awards after its eight nominations.  It surely should have received the Oscar for best original screenplay.  Definitely best costuming.  Then I would have gone all the way and awarded it the Oscar for best film, Russell for best director, and Amy Adams for best actress.  Her performance is so layered and textured.  Her best work!  I have never been a fan of Christian Bale.  But on these multiple viewings, he is getting better and better in this role - very understated and brilliantly executed.  Even the soundtrack( a  strategic selection of 70's music) is a joy!  Maybe American audiences just don't remember (or appreciate) the disco era!!!

Once again, David O. Russell knocks it out of the park with a great ensemble cast, convoluted plot and dark brassy humor.

Okay, as I figured, there are already 443 (!) reviews posted on Amazon for American Hustle.  The BD and DVD were released on March 18th. I wanted to point out that Amazon has a policy of grouping ALL reviews of ALL formats of a film together under each version. So you will find lots of reviews of the theatrical version here as well as review of the Amazon Instant version. Neither of these covers the bonus features on the DVD and Bluray. So I always recommend that buyers sort the reviews by Most Recent first and then look to see which format the reviewer is discussing. With that said, on to my review of the DVD (non-Bluray) version. As I understand it the bonus features are the same on both the DVD and BD.

This 129-minute film is loosely based on the Abscam  sting in the 1970s  though there were never any women involved  (and here there are two) and, for those old enough to remember following the news then, the plot will be more interesting and somewhat easier to follow. I say somewhat because Writer/Director David O. Russell really plays with the real events a lot and often you cant tell who the bad guys (or bad gals) are and who arent.  In one of the special features  more on those in a minute  Russell admits that the plot is really secondary to the characters. He loves quirky characters and thats why he was attracted to the project.  Yes, they are quirky and the 70s clothes and hairstyles bring all the quirkiness out of all the lead actors. Now Amy Adams wears (should I say bare-ly wears?) her dresses that could be popular today. When the plot gets boring there is always Adams to look watch! This is unlike any character she has played before. Jennifer Lawrence is also playing a character unlike her prior roles and that makes it interesting too. But, honestly, I thought the film dragged a lot and that Russell created some scenes just so he could back them with 1970s pop hits.

Because there will be lots of opinions about the film  there already are  Ill now jump to the Bonus Features, and there really aren't many of them either. There are a group of deleted or extended scenes  (about 20 minutes worth) but two of them are just scenes of Jennifer Lawrence dancing around the house while pop hits like Shes A Lady play as a soundtrack. The now-requisite Making of featurette (about 16 minutes) features Russell, some of the cast and a few producers talking about how Russell is so great to work with and how challenging the roles were. And, of course, there are lots of clips from the film.

I enjoyed Russells Silver Linings Playbook, but American Hustle felt like it could have used a bit more editing, and a script that would help explain the whole Abscam thing to younger viewers.

I hope you found this review both informative and helpful.
Steve Ramm

I rented this video, watched a few minutes - next day it just disappeared from my VLibrary.  What gives?  I'd like 1)  money refunded or 2) put it back~!

American Hustle was not what I expected -- I thought it would be just another movie about a scheme to con people. The story is engrossiing and character development exceptional. Even though Christian Bale's character was that of a con man, I found myself rooting for him. His character was deep, moving and complex. Amy Adam's character was equally complex -- I found her quest for a relationship built on honesty refreshing. Loved the ending -- I won't give anything away, but it was very satisfying.
American Hustle was a hustle of viewer.  The nominations over blew this films significance .  They paid more attention to the pretty ladies in this film.

Christian Bale and Amy Adams are so good in this highly entertaining moving.  After getting busted by ambitious FBI agent, they agree to work undercover for the FBI in order to get a reduced sentence. If you haven't seen it, it is well worth the rental.

The movie is good, but not Oscar worthy. The Sting is a much better movie with the same goals. Adams and Bale did their very best acting, which is not truly a complement as they fell short of being able to carry these roles to where they potentially could have gone. Jennefer Lawrence ,on the other hand , was a show stealer and showed she has Oscar level talent. Robert Deniro has a small role and he dominates the scenes like a great white amongst guppies. In fact, since this movie is all about the acting , watching the comparative acting skills is the real game in the movie. The movie itself sets up what is supposed to be a big con and then resolves it so magically, the actual plot is relegated to being irrelevent. Watch this for the acting, then rent The Sting to see how masters carry off what Hustle tried  to do.

I enjoyed the hell out of this movie. It was a blast from start to finish. The actors were perfectly cast, turning in stellar performances It would be hard for me to pick a favorite, although Christian Bale, for me, was a standout. He can really play anything. Bradley Cooper is proving he's the new guy to watch, after Silver Linings Playbook, and now this performance.
 Both Amy Adams and Jennifer Lawrence will have long careers. They have the goods. They may be future Meryl Streeps. I have to mention Louis C. K. He played his part perfectly.
 American Hustle moved at a frenetic pace, thus never leaving you feeling like it was too long or slow. It was one that left me thinking about it the next day. That is the ultimate sign of a great movie for me. I also have to mention how true to the era they were. It was very authentic. I was really glad i got to see this Oscar nominated, David O Russell, gem.
