This is one of the best films of 2013, the film had sort of a goodfellas feel to it, it was like the goodfellas, a crime drama, but with a spice of comedy that will have you rolling and begging for more.  The plot begins with Christian Bale and Amy Adam's characters getting in trouble with the FBI, they were con artists and conned the wrong person; Bradley Cooper's character. Bradley's character cuts them both some slack and has them become informants for the FBI to catch bigger fish, being a 1970's italian mafia movie, there's a lot of big fish to fry. Anyways, without giving too much away, there's a love triangle between the the four character's, Bradley Cooper, Amy Adams, Christian Bale, and the lovely Jennifer Lawrence. AMAZING acting, funny, yet heart breaking drama comedy, this film deserved the nominations it got.. it's truly an instant classic, falls into the classics like Forest Gump, Goodfellas, it's truly an amazing picture that I wouldnt mind seeing again. Jennifer Lawrence played a guidette, poor, single mother that didn't have Christian Bale's character too much in her life, because he was too busy conning people with his partner in crime Amy Adam's... Jennifer Lawrence is loveable, funny, and will bring a tear to your eye... originally she is what brought me to see this movie. Anyways, it was kind of slow in the beginning, getting to know the characters, but man does it pick up, and man what a ride! Must watch! You won't be sorry.

The first time I saw "American Hustle," I didn't. I fell asleep. By what the critics were proclaiming, not only did I miss "the best film of the year," I also slept through it. I had committed a crime against cinema- and as an avid movie-goer, I even felt like I disrespected the art form. Church is what it felt like I'd fallen asleep through, and religious heathens were the ones I felt as if I'd disappointed.

So, in an effort of redemption, I took off to the movie theater that following weekend, highly caffeinated, and more than ready to experience the movie of 2013. I did not fall asleep this time. For two hours and ten minutes I watched... wondering... why my eyes were still open this second time around. "American Hustle," as it turned out, is a film coasting on the popularity of those involved.

The narrative fails to engross and relies completely upon its actors to get the audience through it all. In doing that, the acting is almost always distractingly scenery-chewing. Jennifer Lawrence hams it up in a part meant for someone older; Christian Bale's make up is thicker than his Jersey accent, and everyone else is just deflecting. Louis C.K. is the only one who steals the show simply because it's with very little effort.

David O. Russell, creator of some of my favorites ("Flirting With Disaster," "Silver Linings Playbook"), is the manufacturer of only a decent product here. "American Hustle" is never bad. There are moments that hold interest, but many more that don't. More importantly, there's a showing off-ness permeating throughout the picture that can never be shaken and a glorified reputation that it never amounts to.

In a way, "American Hustle" feels like this monster that climbed the Empire State Building to declare its height, but falls to its death in the process. No, it wasn't the air planes that got him. It was hype killed the beast.

SCORE: C+

Have we been hustled by this film? At times I thought so, a little slow going at first, but then it interrupted into a fast paced film that brought excitement. The film was fashioned after the Abscam affair in the late 80's.

"Abscam--sometimes written ABSCAM--was a Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) sting operation run from the Bureau's Hauppauge, Long Island, office[1] in the late 1970s and early '80s. The operation initially targeted trafficking in stolen property but was converted to a public corruption investigation. The FBI, aided by a convicted con-man, videotaped politicians as they were offered bribes by a fictional Middle Eastern sheik in return for various political favors. The investigation ultimately led to the conviction of a United States Senator, six members of the United States House of Representatives, one member of the New Jersey State Senate, members of the Philadelphia City Council, the Mayor of Camden, New Jersey, and an inspector for the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service." Wiki

Now we see how this entire affair went down, and what we have is a film with superb characters and acting. Christian Bale is the epitome of the com man, and with his intelligence, Amy Adams, good looks and brain, we have one heck of a scam. The FBI enters with Bradley Cooper as the leader of a group,looking for a couple of good arrests for a fame hungry leader. Jennifer Lawerence as Bale's wife knocks the ball out of the park with her role. Jeremy Renner as the mayor of a New Jersey city, always on the make for his city brings truth and life to his role. Every one in this film out did themselves, believable and so ironic. Can a con man con those in the law? Robert DeNiro plays the second in command of a Florida branch of the Mafia. The hair,and I am not talking about Amy Adams, is so awesome. The clothes of the time, the cars, the homes all a remembrance of things past.

This film was one of the better of the season. If not for 12 Years A Slave,this film would have found the Oscar. Kudos to all.

Recommended. prisrob 03-18-14

Imagine a con-artist couple, Irving and Sydney.  They get busted by an FBI agent, Richie, who asks them to help him nab a mayor and a bunch of crooked politicians.  The scheme involves a fake sheik, thousands of dollars that no one wants to put up, the mafia, and Irving's unpredictable, manic-depressive wife Rosalyn.

Sound like a slapstick comedy by way of Martin Scorsese?  It is, sort of.  David O. Russell's AMERICAN HUSTLE is an homage to a decade, and an attempt to hone in on some of the classic Scorsese vibe.  A bit too much, at times--the style seems a bit of a rip-off at times, especially when paired with the (admittedly great) soundtrack.  In fact, as good a director as Russell can be, this film is elevated by its script (courtesy of Russell and Eric Warren Singer, featuring fantastic dialogue, some true emotional grit, and a couple nice twists) and the acting.  Christian Bales gives a complex, nuanced performance, which slowly grows as we learn more about Irving.  Amy Adams is dynamite; Bradley Cooper makes his jerk FBI agent sympathetic (but not so much that we ever truly like hime); Jeremy Renner doesn't get a whole lot to do as a pawn in the scheme, but he's clearly having fun.  Aside from Bale, it's Jennifer Lawrence who steals the scenes; like Bale's, her performance grows in complexity as the film progresses.  Sure, she's playing an older character; but it was only when a friend brought it up that I realized she's just 3 days shy of being exactly 4 years younger than me.  Like Bale, who becomes a pot-bellied, balding schlub with a combover, she nailed it.

Kudos also goes to a cameo appearance from a film legend that I won't ruin, because it was a genuine (and pleasant) surprise for me.

AMERICAN HUSTLE is one of those films that screams, "Give me an Oscar!"  Perhaps David O. Russell is a little desperate at this point.  That being said, it truly is an enjoyable film, at parts funny, at parts dramatic.  It leans a bit on Scorsese's filmography (particularly GOODFELLAS), but the acting is top-notch, the script is solid, and the overall experience has a few nice thrills.  Maybe it's not worthy of 10 Oscar nominations (and no wins, another Scorsese comparison you can make), but it's certainly one of the better movie experiences out there.

I kind of love that this movie opens with the clever disclaimer Some of this actually happened because it sets a tone that pays off, mostly, for this energetic and enjoyable romp from David O. Russell.  Russell is a director who has been getting a lot of flak over the past few years (and his past few films) for selling out; leaving his former eccentric formula of filmmaking for a more commercial and Oscary trajectory.  I honestly didn't care too much either way.  The only Russell film that I really like is I Heart Huckabees, which is actually very different from any of his other films Ive seen.  Granted, I haven't seen Flirting With Disaster (which I hear is a favorite among his fans) but I seem to find some kernel of something I dislike about all his films, sans I Heart Huckabees.

Still, I was kind of excited about American Hustle.  Ill admit, when the project was first announced I wasn't very interested.  I liked some of the cast and was disinterested in the other half.  Bale and Adams are usually reliable presences, and while I was never a fan BEFORE Silver Linings Playbook, I became a fan of Jennifer Lawrence based on that spirited performance and her tactless charm.  Still, I kind of hate Jeremy Renner and find Bradley Cooper annoying.

But then the trailer was dropped and it looked like such fun!

For me, American Hustle kind of feels like an eccentrically commercial film, so maybe this is the perfect lane for Russell, who obviously wants that Oscar.  Im still shocked that this so heavily over-performed with Oscar (racking up TEN Oscar nominations) and yet failed to win a single award, but AMPAS is obviously responding well to Russells directorial direction, so Im sure its only a matter of time.

Like I said; I couldn't honestly care less, but whatever.

The film is loosely based the ABSCAM federal con-job of the 70s.  Im not entirely familiar with the real story, so I have no idea what of this actually happened, but this was intricately plotted fun, and while there are some plotting issues, this film mostly succeeds because of an ample cast and some sharp direction.  Yes, David O. Russell has some serious fun with this one; point to point.

Here we have Irving Rosenfeld, a charismatic con man who gets himself in a sticky situation when he gets busted by an over ambitious FBI agent named Richie DiMaso.  Irvings partner, Sydney, is pulled into Richies web of charm and while Richies grip on Irving and Sydney tightens with his proposition to them, she begins playing the field herself; turning tables with a subtle allure.  You see, Richie wants bigger names than Irving Rosenfeld, and so he offers Irving a clean slate if he helps entrap four big names.  He sets his sights on Carmine Polito; an ambitious New Jersey mayor looking to make a better life for the kids in his community.  With his passions and Irvings persistence, the con is in place to make Richie a big name in his unit.

But Irvings crazy wife, Rosalyn, could ruin everything.

The energy here is pretty great, and that is thanks to all the sharp editing tricks.  Some films really rely on those cuts to create the needed tone, and this one has that in spades.  I kind of found the dialog here really pedestrian, so while the whole plot unraveling and twists here and there were intriguing and wholly engaged, the dialog in some key scenes was just distracting.  Thankfully, actors like Jennifer Lawrence and Bradley Cooper knew how to take those ridiculous lines and make them feel soulful and spirited.  The cast all works really, and I was surprised with how much I really liked Jeremy Renner here (who was honestly best in show).  A lot of people balked at Lawrences high octane performance and her battle with the accent, but she was just so hilariously layered here.  Her confrontation scene with Adams, despite some shoddy dialog (seriously Russell?) was so human.  Adams accent work, although part of the film itself, was more distracting simply because it was so unbelievably uneven that I cant imagine anyone would fall for it, let along an FBI Agent.

But like I said, this was a lot of fun, and while I would have trimmed this down a tad, I cant say that I want my time back.

David O. Russell's "American Hustle" tells a mostly fictionalized account ('some of this is true' a title says) of the 1980's 'Abscam' scandal in which an eccentric FBI agent exposed corruption in political figures in Pennsylvania and New Jersey.  That just begins to describe this top-notch entertainment with idiosyncratic characters that fascinate as they make you laugh.  Virtually everyone is at the peak of their form.

Christian Bale plays Irving Rosenfeld (the fictional version of real-life Melvin Weinberg), a con-artist who is 'drafted' into working with the FBI to expose corruption during the "Abscam" scandals, and he's a joy to watch. Amy Adams is Sydney Prosser, seductive British partner to Bale's Irving Rosenfeld, and it's her best role to date.  She's both funny and sexy as she works several different men in the FBI scheme she's been 'drafted' into.  Jennifer Lawrence is also one of the pleasures of "American Hustle", garnering some of the film's biggest laughs without ever forsaking the believability of her character.

David O. Russell has had a good record of making extremely enjoyable films, and many of them display a great sense of artistic achievement.  He started in the early nineties with some provocative and daring independent films ("Spanking the Monkey" and "Flirting with Disaster", two marvelous black comedies) before making his first masterpiece "Three Kings" in 1999, a darkly comic war film about the first Iraqi conflict, starring George Clooney and Mark Wahlberg.  His subsequent films went from the esoteric and incomprehensible "I Heart Huckabees" to more grounded filmmaking with "The Fighter" and "Silver Linings Playbook", both Oscar winners and both excellent showcases for actors.  Some say Russell seems to emulate Martin Scorsese's direction here (especially the early parts of "Goodfellas" sans violence), but is that a bad thing?  Russell, even in his less accomplished films, has always had an affinity for directing actors masterfully, but in "American Hustle" he excelled himself in juggling his superb cast in a perfectly integrated ensemble.

This is certainly a film that no film lover should miss.

As I utilize reviews from time to time, I decided to make a contribution on this film.

It was fabulous.  If you need to watch something that will UNCONDITIONALLY get your head out of where-ever you are, this film will do it from the first second on.  The writing and acting are first class.

We saw it at an advanced screening, and it was the best film of the year without a doubt.  I honestly don't know what the detractors are complaining about, unless it's that the Golden Globes nominated it in the wrong category: this is NOT a comedy, but a drama with some comedy, which is true with all good dramas. If people go into a movie expecting a rip roaring laugh fest and instead see something totally different they're going to be disappointed.  The acting is superb and the script is wonderful,  I even saw complaints about the costumes of all things, but anyone who lived during the era knows that yes, people really did dress that way (not me, but I had more taste than that).  Halston even allowed his originals to be used in the film.  This film deserved to win a number of Oscars: the mystery is why it didn't.

I have been waiting for this to come out on DVD.  I love many of the actors in this film, and with all the nominations, expected to be really impressed.  I was actually kind of bored and turned it off to go do something else about an hour in. I will watch the end sometime - not saying it is unwatchable by any means.  But I expected this to be a lot more engaging than it was.  Amy Adams turns in a fine piece of work, but the movie overall was just not that engaging.  I expected another great performance from Jennifer Lawrence, but I was kind of underwhelmed.  Her part seemed a little cartoony - we've seen it before.  Lots of elements in her character from jersey girl - mob wife types in other movies.  Maybe if her part were bigger, she could have done more with it.  There is some good acting among the major characters, but overall, it just didn't do it for me.
Could have done without the first hour of the movie; dragged out, almost became nap time.  Second hour was much better.

It is the worst movie I have every seen. Did not evening watch it to the end. Would not even tell
my worst friend about this movie.

I really wanted this to be a good movie, but alas!, in my opinion, it was awful.  No point to it whatsoever.  The best parts were when Jennifer Lawrence made her on screen appearances, but I don't think she was on screen more than 10 or 15 minutes.  Too bad, it had great promise, wonderful actors. great director.  It just didn't jell..........

The acting in "American Hustle" is superb. It's no wonder Christian Bale, Bradley Cooper, Amy Adams, and Jennifer Lawrence all received Oscar nominations, as did this picture. with an ending that stuns. It's complicated, so it takes a lot of attention, and it's also filled with comedy and pathos; with an ending that stuns. A beautifully written movie based on an actual sting operation in the late 70s.
Not really what I expected, I was very disappointed. My wife went to bed half way through it and I would say she really didn't miss much with this movie.

I call b.s. This looks and feels every bit like a Scorsese movie  from the voiceover, the way the shots are framed, the camera movement, the use of music, and ESPECIALLY the acting style employed by each of the lead actors. David O. Russell hasn't found his voice (I'm disappointed in you, Charlie Rose). He found Martin Scorseses. It's the most blatant ripoff of Goodfellas since Casino.
Great movie! J. Law steals the show! Everyone does a fantastic job of bringing the characters to life and you really feel for them.
It was one of the greatest movies from last year and was robbed during award season. The performances make the movie, but the writing and costume design was well done too.

"American Hustle" begins with one of the best opening scenes in recent memory. Before we see anything else, we see Christian Bale -- the guy who played millionaire playboy Bruce Wayne not that long ago -- meticulously arranging, pasting, and spraying into place a terribly elaborate and truly hideous comb over. It's funny, and it tells us volumes about this character. He's a con man, a master at the art of deception, and a very careful one. Every detail has to be exactly right, "from the feet up" -- all the way up to the fake hair.

But he's gotten himself into a situation where nothing's right, everything is slapdash, and he's out of control. It's only a matter of time before he ends up in prison, or worse. That's all thanks to Bradley Cooper, an FBI agent who caught on to one of his small time schemes, and is using it as leverage against him and his partner, Amy Adams into larger and ever more dangerous schemes, until they're looking at taking down powerful politicians, and ending up on the wrong side of the mob. Bale isn't happy about any of this; he's a small fish happy in his big pond; he'd rather be scamming gambling addicts than having a sitdown with Robert De Niro.

Some of this actually happened. The film is based on the "Abscam" scandal from the late '70s, loosely. The historical situation is pretty crazy in and of itself, and indicative of the dysfunction in American government and culture in the '70s. ("Argo" this ain't.) In a nutshell, the FBI grew tired of being reprimanded by Congress, so the feds launched an operation against Congress itself. It involved a fake "Arab" seeking to invest millions into New Jersey's slumping economy, and willing to grease whatever palms necessary to get the casino licenses, citizenship and anything else needed to get the job done. Abscam brought down several Representatives and one Senator on bribery charges, but it also resulted in something called the "Civiletti Undercover Guidelines," which basically was the Attorney General telling the FBI to never do anything like it ever again.

It's a situation a little too messy for a straightforward film adaptation, but David O. Russell likes to make messy movies. Russell's signature talent is his ability to both create and control chaos onscreen. He loves to set crazy characters on colliding paths, and knows there are infinite ways to play crazy. It's hard to imagine any other director managing the scenes Russell manages, scenes in which three or four or five crazy people bounce off of each other at odd angles in fantastically entertaining ways.  He's also skilled at swinging from zany to serious (and back) at the drop of a hat. It's kind of like watching Real Housewives: these people are nuts, but we care about them anyway. Actually, it's infinitely more entertaining than Real Housewives.

Russell has developed a consistent stable of actors he likes to work with -- or who like to work with him. Rumor has it he's an extremely demanding director, known for feeding improvised lines to actors from alongside the camera during shooting. Also, there's a video on YouTube of him ranting and raving at Lily Tomlin during the shooting of "I Heart Huckabees," though Tomlin afterward said that everything was fine between them and she'd be happy to work with him again. Some can't take the heat, and some thrive in it.

Amy Adams is better in Russell's movies than in anything else she's done, and so is Bradley Cooper. Cooper has earned Oscar nominations for his two performances in Russell's films, despite playing basically the same character in both of them (manic and naive, goal-driven, desperate, prone to violent outbursts but somehow forgivable and even innocent.) I'm not convinced yet that Cooper is a great actor--I'd like to see more range in his performances -- but he has without a doubt created a very watchable character performance that can span multiple films. In that way he's kind of like Al Pacino or Woody Allen.

Christian Bale, on the other hand, is a man of a thousand faces (and mannerisms, accents, etc.) If the Oscar always goes to the actor who uglies up best, Christian Bale got robbed. He gained 50 lbs and looks terrible. I guess that's not as impressive at Matthew McConaughey losing 50 lbs., but McConaughey is still rodeo-sexy through most of Dallas Buyers Club. Bale just looks bad here, and that's good. It's amazing to me that the same guy can play Batman, Patrick Bateman and a crackhead boxing has-been who once knocked down Sugar Ray Leonard (or maybe he just tripped.)

But Jennifer Lawrence, who can seemingly do anything, might be the best part of the movie. She plays Bale's wife, whom he can't seem to get away from (he calls her "the Picasso of passive-aggressive karate.") She routinely steals scenes by playing absolutely, but uniquely and distinctly, bats*** crazy. She's the opposite of her nail finish--she's mostly rotten and a little bit sweet, and you can't get enough of her. You just keep coming back.

"American Hustle" is a zany, screwball ride, but it's also a movie about survival and reinvention. It's about people who are conning themselves, who are desperate to get out of their situations and maybe their skins. Ironically, the only characters who have a firm grasp on their real identities are the cons. Bradley Cooper thinks he's a hotshot FBI agent, but really he's small potatoes with too much ambition and not enough ethics or loyalty. Jeremy Renner thinks he's a big-hearted mayor who does everything for the people of New Jersey, but he's on the take, and in bed with the mafia. Best of all is Jennifer Lawrence, who thinks she's taking care of her family by setting the microwave on fire and "motivating" her husband by nearly getting him killed.  Amy Adams, meanwhile, grows tired of playing a part and just wants someone to be real with, and Christian Bale knows he's a small time crook and has no appetite for bigger fish. In the world these characters live in, ambition is the greatest sin -- ambition and lying to your friends.

Random Notes:

I loved Louis C.K. as Cooper's boss.  The ice fishing story!

Amy Adams British accent is terrible... but is it terrible on purpose?  She's a stripper from Albuquerque, after all.  If so, what does it take for an actress to purposely affect a bad accent?

I didn't like Jeremy Renner.  His performance was the only one in the film that didn't work for me.  He's supposed to be New Jersey through and through, but take away the hair, and he might as well be from Orange County.

This keeps getting compared to Scorsese and "Goodfellas," but the similarities seem superficial to me (the costumes, big songs on the soundtrack) Russell definitely has his own voice as a director.

The acting in this movie was amazing and I felt that it had a lot of potential. But I kept feeling like I was waiting for something to happen. I didn't feel like the twist at the end was enough. Just felt like it needed more. But Christian Bale was absolutely amazing!!
Great story.  Great acting.  Great period piece.  Definitely worth the time.  Enjoy going back in time.  Do the Hustle and have fun.

I hate to sound rude but.... the truth is, my perception is that those who gave this movie horrible ratings or claim they "fell asleep" is simply because they just could not keep up with the plot. You have to truly pay attention to every detail, but boy does it pay off. The twist ending rivals that of Catching Fire (for those who didn't read the books.) The acting is phenomenal, there was no stand-out because every character played his/her role to absolute perfection. I especially loved Jennifer Lawrence as the psycho, bi-polar wife of the famous con-man, as she manages to come across as someone you absolutely cannot stand while maintaining a sexy, untamed woman's pull which you can easily see why she has such a pull on Bale. The chemistry between all the main characters is something you can't make up. The wit of the con artists is impeccable, perhaps because it is based on actual events, but Adams, Bale and Cooper pull it off in a sense that would make you think they themselves were the subjects of the sting. I saw this in theaters, and it was one of those movies where you debate peeing your pants because you don't want to miss a second. It's hard to compare this to any other movies because it's so unique, but if I were to compare it to other movies of the same caliber that I myself like to give potential viewers an idea of what they might get.... I'd say if you liked Casino, Goodfellas, Blow, etc., you'll love this. Also, I saw this with FOUR friends, all of us with different tastes in movies, two of us were excited to see this, two were not, but we all left giddy and wanting to go back to the time period it happened and live the lives of the characters (even though they were criminals, we wanted their lives... goes to show how well they sold their parts!) So again, I can't help but speculate that the people who claim they were 'bored' or 'fell asleep' simply did not understand the movie because maybe they were expecting a Hollywood Blockbuster with predictable plot twists and endings like most movie-goers. Don't let those people deter you from seeing this. If you end up truly hating it, which I doubt, at least you
Great acting jobs from pretty much everyone the film.. Just a horrible and painful movie to watch. spent the entire time waiting for anything to happen. just never did. save your money
Horrible awful movie that I hated. I could not stay awake. I would rather mash my face 20 times into a concrete wall than watch it again. HATED IT!

This was the best movie my husband and I saw last year, and we see a lot of films. It is loosely based on a true story that those of you old enough to remember the '70s will recall. The acting is amazingly good. Every actor. It is tense at times and also laugh out loud funny. I am shocked that it doesn't have a higher rating here. Most enjoyable time I had at the theater all year. I highly recommend this movie.

I really wanted to see what the fuss was about. The wonderfully put together Oscar worthy movie. I hate long reviews so in short- I watched 1/4, paused, later watched another 1/4, paused, another, paused, and then I decided that there was no way I could get through the last 1/4 of the movie. I pushed myself to get past the last 3/4. It was so so bad, and I love Jennifer Lawrence and I Lovvvvvve me some Bradly Cooper, but..............

It's not Casino, but it was okay. It really wasn't anything to "write home about" Didn't blow me away that's for sure. It was missing something: 10 Best Pic Nominations? I don't think it was that great. Kind of disappointed I paid $15 for it and now own it on Prime Instant Video. I probably won't ever watch it again but I can at least let my friends and family view it and save them the money.
The best movie I've seen this year!  Amy Adams is at her best and, in my opinion st least, deserved the Oscar for best actress.

Impressive acting, artistic...

You want everyone to win, and you want everyone to lose.  If that's not a good movie, I don't know what is.  And the soundtrack is impeccable.

We really enjoyed this movie. It is a well written and performed movie with excellent character development without pandering to any particular interest group. It had no chance of winning the Oscar against 12 Years a Slave or Dallas Buyers Club - when you're up against an excellent movie with those kind of messages, you have no chance of winning.

It is not a "substance" movie. It's based loosely on the Abscam cases when the FBI set-up a bunch of politicians and caught them with their hands in the cookie jar, but the plot is just there to tie the characters together.

While she did an excellent job, I don't think Jennifer Lawrence's performance was Oscar worthy. Amy Adam's and Christian Bale's performances were stellar and each should have won.

While it is a lengthy movie, I would not cut anything.

Christian Bale hustles a 5 star performance in American Hustle. There are a few things here and there during the rest of American Hustle, that was so close to being a five star movie, that slightly lowered it to a four star movie. American Hustle, while fine overall, was worth watching especially for the worthy of an award acting by Christian Bale.

Boy was I disappointed, the movie is just a mess, it started slowly as a drama, then it looked like it was going to get really good, I was thinking, wow it maybe this generations "Goodfellas" but the story just fell flat, genre jumping insued on multiple occasions, leaving you with the question, what am I watching, a drama? a gangster flim? or worse still a bad comedy?

The acting was good but it was a boring, icky movie. There weren't any likable characters and the story was just bland. Last year, a film about a top-secret 1979 CIA mission to rescue American diplomats during the Iranian hostage crisis took home the best picture Oscar.  This year, David O. Russell looks to keep this trend alive with American Hustle, a stylish story about the top-secret 1978 FBI sting operation, ABSCAM.

David O. Russell has been an exciting filmmaker for several years now.  His previous three films, The Fighter, Silver Linings Playbook, and now American Hustle, have thrust Russells notoriety into a new echelon, however, by examining his previous quirky, clever, and unique films, Russells evolution can be clearly perceived.  1996s Flirting With Disaster showed Russells quirky comedic tone.  In what some consider his best film, 1999s Three Kings showcased Russells clever style.  Additionally, 2004s I Heart Huckabees solidifies Russells unique writing.  Now it seems hes hit his stride as his previous three films represent all three of these talents repurposed and mixed with tremendous results.

Russells renaissance involves making films about memorable characters with his emerging cast of regular actors.  Christian Bale, Bradley Cooper, Robert DeNiro, Jennifer Lawrence, and Amy Adams have all been in at least two of his last three films, and all of them have received at least one Oscar nomination as a result  including two winners.  While rumors swirl around Russells ease to work with, he is able to coax performances from his actors like none other, and American Hustle is no exception.

American Hustle opens against the gritty backdrop of 1978 New Jersey with a tone-setting title card that reads Some of this actually happened.  We are immediately introduced to con man Irving Rosenfeld (Christian Bale) who runs a fledgling at best money lending scheme.  That all changes when he meets the seductive Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams) at a party.  As a team, they bring Rosenfelds scheme to the next level attracting the attention of FBI agent Richie DiMaso (Bradley Cooper).  DiMaso uses his leverage on the two con-artists to coerce them to cooperate with him in a series of operations designed to entrap high ranking politicians and power brokers including New Jersey Mayor Carmine Polito (Jeremy Renner).

Now the story might seem complex enough as it is, but under the guise that some of this actually happened, Russell does this story one better with the introduction of Irvings impulsive wife Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence) who could be the one who sends this whole operation crashing down.

Bale gives another transformative performance, this time with an added 60 pounds, a comb-over, and a Bronx accent.  Adams continues her quest to become this generations Kevin Bacon by being in a movie with every relevant actor in existence.  She also gives a very strong performance as the mysterious Sydney who is hell-on-wheels wrapping every man around her finger and perpetually driving Irving crazy in the process.  Lawrence steals every scene she is in as Irvings wildly capricious wife who won't grant him a divorce and doesnt know how to use a science oven either.  Renner and Cooper are very effective at representing both sides of the law in this wildly outrageous story where the line between hero and villain is very, very thin.

Mayor Polito wants nothing more than to re-invent Atlantic City and make New Jersey a better place, but with his hands tied politically, he seeks the necessary capital from a seemingly interested Arab investor who is actually part of agent DiMasos operation.  Thus, what makes American Hustle most intriguing is Russells conscientious effort to construct an irony where con-men and FBI agents are working together to ostensibly take down a criminal who may be the most honorable character in the film.  American Hustle does have one element working against it, running time.  At around 130 minutes, most of which is rapid dialogue, the film feels a bit bloated.  There are many characters and they all have a lot to say.  From an acting standpoint, it is quite impressive, but from an audience standpoint the film slags a bit through its second half.

There is plenty to like about American Hustle, far more than whats not to like.  For those looking for an amazingly well made and well acted film that does not include the brutality of slavery or the primal fear of being lost in space, this is your movie.  B+

American Hustle is rated R and has a running time of 2 hours and 9 minutes.  Keep any eye out for some great and surprising faces in some of the supporting roles.

Christian Bale never disappoints me, Amy Adams shines in her role and Jennifer Lawrence steals every scene she's in.
Brady Cooper and the rest of the cast put in very strong performances, I found the direction to be a poor mans version of a Scorsese movie. David O. Russell obviously is heavely influenced by Martin Scorsese and it shows in this film.
A definite must watch.

The first half of this film is slow but the second half picks up, which is where Jennifer Lawrence shows up the most. Many of the scenes did remind me of New Jersey and the areas I grew up; there is this one scene where they show the mayor's house and I could swear I saw this house in Haddonfield. Amy Adams has never been my favorite actress but she did an amazing job and, in my humble opinion, she beat out Cate Blanchett in Blue Jasmine (Yes I saw that movie too). The camera angles are sometimes off in the movie, I found myself wishing the camera would pan out so I could see all the actors who were talking, but I think the director was going for an authentic 70s movie feel. So this movie is a good watch and if you start it and find it is slow give it about 45 minutes and it picks up. The last scene between Christian Bale and Jennifer Lawrence is Amazing.

...at least for Best Screenplay and I would've given it Best Film as well. I saw this in the theater and it's one of the better movies I've seen in a while. Not perfect, but very, very good. Vivid, watchable characters making mistakes, being impossible and getting stuck in their impossible selves - just like people in real life. The performances from all the actors are excellent and the scene-writing is both tight and twisty. My favorite: Irving (played by Christian Bale) goes into unload on Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence) and winds up thanking her.

Favorite dialogue (except I can't remember it exactly): (Irving) "You shouldn't do anything to someone you wouldn't want them to do to you. I think Jesus said that."

(Carmine) "Yeah?"

(Irving) "Also, always take the favor over the money. I think Jesus said that, too."

If you enjoy dialogue like that you'll probably enjoy this movie. Also, '70s hits.

After seeing the trailer, cast list, and critic reviews for American Hustle, I forked out the money to see it on the big screen. This film may be worthy of a nominee for the acting, costumes, or the like, but as a whole, the film was a disappointment. The storyline was nothing that fully drew me in nor connected me to the characters. Certainly a movie worth watching as a rental simply to enjoy the superb acting, but not worth buying.

Not exactly sure what everyone is talking about with this movie? A good imitation of the 1970s? Yeah, sure. Yawn. Boring. Nothing all that intelligent or worth watching. Certainly nothing new. Sad that some of the great actors in this movie actually bought into this being a good movie. Love the actors/actresses. But nothing really redeems a movie that is really just fluff and attempts at some sort of "art" that is good only to "artists" and not in the rest of the world. Whatever scale this is rated on, I can't imagine it's something anyone might watch again, and certainly not in 30 years.

Suggested by actual events of the Abscam sting in the 1970s, the FBI plans to setup and arrest corrupt politicians. How they get the officials and the professional con artists that help the sting operation are the basis of a nostalgic film.  As directed and co-written by David O. Russell (Silver Linings Playbook, The Fighter), American Hustle is an acting clinic highlighting a convoluted tale of men and women who are looking for a big score.

In 1978, ambitious FBI agent Richie DiMaso (Bradley Cooper), forces con man Irving Rosenfeld (Christian Bale) and his mistress, Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams), to help arrange a con on white collar crime, specifically targeting corrupt politicians.  Richie wants to make a name for himself, and he is immediately attracted to Sydney and has designs on her beyond the con.  Starting with a local, beloved mayor, Carmine Polito (Jeremy Renner), high level political figures are drawn in, and there is the possible organized crime connection. Further, Irvings wife, Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence), threatens to derail the sting.  As Richies grand plan comes together, things get more complicated and risky, and Irving and Sydney must rely on their skills to survive.

These are very well etched characters.  Each has something to gain, and each has an angle to exploit, whether its Richies dreams of a big bust or Rosalyns threats to expose the operation.  Kindred souls and survivors, Irving and Sydney have mastered the art of deception and manipulation.  You feel a degree of sympathy for Irving despite his criminal past and his marital discord.  Not only does he love his women, but he tries to save a friend from jail.  Irving turns out to be someone to root for.  In fact the world is not black and white especially when an FBI agent breaks the rules and gets involved with one of the principals.  Carmine is the noble, elected official who truly believes in doing good for his community.  Just who are the good guys and bad guys? Just who is conning who?

Memorable scenes include a catty confrontation in a womens restroom, the faceoff between Richie and his beleaguered boss (played to great effect by Louis C. K.), and an incredibly tense meeting with a head mobster (Robert DeNiro in a lethal cameo).

Acting is superior throughout as expected in a Russell ensemble with the principals at the top of their game.  Bale transforms his physical appearance as an overweight, balding schlep (a far cry from The Dark Knights Batman).  A sultry Adams (Doubt, Her) has a great time playing a kindred con artist with a British accent.  Cooper (Limitless, The Hangover) has a ball as the gung ho agent with a 1970s perm who will step over his boss to get his time in the sun.  Lawrence (The Hunger Games, Winters Bone) excels as the wife who exhibits a bold brashness in public which delights her onlookers but risks blowing the sting.

There is liberal use of 1970s pop songs which blend with the costumes and hair styles seamlessly.  The camera work is fluid and is reminiscent of early Martin Scorsese films. There is a very carefree attitude in the films look and feel which is consistent with this loose, uninhibited decade.

A slice of the seventies with freewheeling hustlers and loose morals, at its core, American Hustle is a love story centering on Irving, an imperfect con artist and the women in his life.  The film is essentially a con within a con and keeps you guessing until the end.  Although the films narrative is not as tight as it could have been, Russell has sacrificed a tiny bit of substance for style.  Do admire this film for the many scenes that pit flawed characters against each other.  Acting does not get much better than this.

One of the most boring movies I ever saw.  I kept waiting for it to get good, and that never happened.  I don't care how good the acting was, I could hardly keep my eyes open.  I debated turning it off.  Hollywood is crazy to give this any awards.  I would give it a negative 2 stars if I could.

Saw reviews and heard the talk about this movie and thought it might be good.  Went to the theatre and spent the whole movie wanting to get up and leave.  All these big name actors and the movie was such a pain to watch.  Should have went with my usual method of deciding to watch a movie if the critics love it, its not generally worth watching.  Don't waste your money buying if you must see it redbox/netflix it.  Not worth owning.

I thought this movie was fantastic. It had comedy, great music, great acting, cast, gorgeous women, and a great twist for an ending. It is a must see and i will be dissapointed if it does not win an Oscar.

American Hustle is the best film I've seen in years. The plot was funny, each character was a gem, and the acting was superb. I hadn't read about the film before I went to see it, so I didn't know who the actors were going to be. I kept trying to figure out who was playing the lead character, but I never did. When the credits rolled, I was astonished to learn that it was Christian Bale. Now, that's real acting when someone so well-known was not even recognizable to me in that new role. My opinion of Mr. Bale's acting ability really zoomed at that point because I've gotten tired of long-time actors just playing themselves again and again in new films. But, the other actors in this film all did a fine job, too. I'm going to buy the DVD so that I can see the bits of dialogue on captions that I missed hearing at the theatre.

Hype towards a movie can easily ruin your experience with it, time and time again. You see all the awards it's been getting, amazing quotes from critics, and your expectations are set way too high. Then, when you actually see it, you're totally disappointed, and expected something much better. That's exactly what happened when I first saw "American Hustle". I liked it a lot, but not as much as other people seemed too. When I decided to see it a second time, I tried to put all the hype aside, and I enjoyed the movie considerably more.

 The film follows Irving Rosenfeld, played by Christian Bale, a con-man who runs a corrupt loan business alongside his seductive partner Sydney (Amy Adams). When busted by FBI agent Richie DiMaso (Bradley Cooper), he is obliged to work together with him to lineup the arrests of several other people including congressmen and mafia members.

With awesome costumes and music choices that set you right in the time period, the movie is enchanting from the start. It may be a tad too long, but the cast of off-beat and interesting characters make up for that in the end. Christian Bale is certainly the standout, and seeing his performance a second time solidified that. Go in with a clear head, and you will most-definitely enjoy it. Rated R for language and sexual content, "American Hustle" is enchantingly good.

A con artist duo Irving Rosenfeld (Christian Bale gaining about 50 pounds for the role) and Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams) are forced to work for an overachieving FBI agent Richie DiMaso (Bradley Cooper) who wants to catch a bigger prey. Their plans for additional arrests get out of control when some persons (including one crime figure) get involved in an unexpected way.

Directed by David O. Russell (Silver Linings Playbook), American Hustle boasts an impressive cast including Jennifer Lawrence and Jeremy Renner, plus one veteran Oscar winner in a cameo role.

However, considering the unique subject matter of a real-life sting operation ABSCAM, and stellar cast as well as the great soundtrack (including some rare ELO tracks), American Hustle should have been more engaging. The films dialogue-heavy script, especially the first half of it, suffers from the uneven pace, sometimes feeling like sprawling not knowing where to go. Actor all did great job, though Jennifer Lawrence seems miscast in a role that should be much older.

The film begins with words Some of this actually happened. Thats fine with me as long as the result interests us. Despite the great material, however, I somehow couldn't find the film that way.

Watching  "American Hustle" is like going to an art gallery to view a new piece of art all the critics are drooling and raving over. I stand before this art "masterpiece", and see nothing but a twisted mess of rusted pipes, and thinking ,"HUH? I don't get it". That's  my reaction to this movie. I don't get it. Why are all the critics raving about it, and WHY is this movie winning all the awards? Loosely based on the Abscam stings of the late 70's and early 80's, I did think the acting was very good, and anyone who could dream up this screenplay deserves some type of recognition. For me, it was an overlong parade of Amy Adams displaying $8,000 worth of hair extensions, and clothing cut to her navel, Christian Bale with a pathetic comb over, Jeremy Renner with a ridiculous pompadour, and Bradley Cooper with his white man's afro. At least the "dos" gave me which gave me something to watch, because otherwise the movie was pointless, and actually, boring. My biggest thought watching it was, when is thing going to end? Reading about all the praise being heaped on this movie, proved to me, critics don't always know what they are talking about, so don't take their reviews as gospel. If this movie goes on to win the Oscar for best picture, over films so much better, it will be the greatest joke since 'Saving Private Ryan" lost.

David O Russell teams up again with actors from his previous films - Bradley Cooper, Jennifer Lawrence and uncredited Robert de Niro from Silver Linings Playbook; Christian Bale and Amy Adams from The Fighter. One thing is guaranteed - starring in a Russell movie will get you a nomination or a win at the various awards. (Melissa Leo won an Oscar for the Fighter - who can forget her acceptance speech?). This is no exception - apart from Robert de Niro's brief cameo, all four of the abovementioned actors have been nominated for Academy Awards for their roles in this movie, with a couple of award wins to date. With such a stellar cast, how can it miss?

Christian Bale once again immerses himself fully into his character - con man Irving Rosenfeld - padding an extra 50 pounds onto his frame. His portrayal of the psychotic wraith Trevor Reznik in The Machinist, for which he lost 60 pounds was spellbinding. Robert de Niro's cameo as Victor Telegio was brilliant!

But Jennifer Lawrence (Rosalyn Rosenfeld), an exceptionally versatile actress, is simply too young to be convincing in her role, despite her outstanding performance. She is 23, but could easily pass for 18. Amy Adams' (Sidney Tosser/Edith Greensley) inconsistent accent, can't make up its mind whether to be British or American (with even the occasional Aussie twang).  She does not switch easily between her twin roles. She is just too scrawny to exude sex appeal - her low cut dresses hint at boobs, not cleavage. The neurotic but ambitious Bradley Cooper as FBI agent Richie diMaso, with his tightly permed hair is so OTT as to degenerate into a caricature. His mannerisms are Jewish, his appearance Arabic/Jewish - he ain't no Italian! His hysterical temper tantrums, evident in Silver Linings Playbook, may stereotype him for future roles. The supporting cast did better overall, particularly Jeremy Renner's Mayor Carmine Polito and Louis C.K. as Cooper's much abused supervisor Stoddard Thorsen.

Without spoilers, the movie is a sting operation, with con artists Bale and Adams being forced to team up with Cooper for immunity when they get caught red handed. Loosely based on the ABSCAM scandals of the 70s and 80s, it is drawn out, overwrought and failed to hold my attention, despite a few really funny throwaway scenes . At over 2 hours, it is too long.

It just goes to show that despite a muddled plot, overlong scenes and some mediocre acting, not uncommonly the voters on The Oscars, Golden Globes, Baftas etc. clearly see merit where I don't. As always, far more deserving actors/movies are ignored out there. Joaquin Phoenix, despite numerous nominations, failed to win a single award for Walk the Line. Go figure. . .

Watch it if you must, but in a week's time, you will have forgotten it.

American Hustle is a great film, or I should say, a great American film. This is a fascinating movie that delves deep into America's society and culture, by way of a fast and complex story of the 1970's AbScam, filled with wonderfully written and brilliantly acted characters. Fast, funny and even a bit sad, American Hustle is not casual viewing, even though it's one of the best times you'll have at the movies all year. A second viewing of this film is highly rewarded, and recommended. I LOVE THIS MOVIE!!!

A con-man and his partner (in this case Bale and Adams) try to pull a big con on a bigger crook.

Essentially this was also the plot of THE STING

AMERICAN HUSTLE shows what THE STING would have been like if it had a script with no characters with appeal, with many digressions and meaningless plot padding; with a director who didn't know how to pace a story for effect and a creative team who were a lot less entertaining than they thought they were.

THE STING did not have these deficiencies and was justly praised and loved. AMERICAN HUSTLE, in its success at the box office, says more about the continuing decline of the taste of movie watchers than it does about anything else.

This is the most putrid overrated movie I have ever seen! It's soulless and empty! I kept waiting for something to happen and nothing happened! If you wanna watch a truly overwhelmingly funny movie, watch The Wolf of Wall street, you will never regret it.
Bad script, poor arc, a muddled mess.  Sure the acting is great, but other than that it's an empty shell.  I seriously have no idea why people are raving about this movie.  It's mediocre at best.

This is an interesting -- if slowly paced film.  The beginning is complicated because you have no idea who is who or what is going on.  It begins to clear as you realize that a politician (later identified as the mayor of Camden NJ is being offered a bribe.  Then with the flash backs the other characters come into focus as you come to know Irving -- a scam artist and Sydney his sidekick.  Then one of their victims turns out to be an undercover FBI Agent.  An agent on the prowl for recognition but undisciplined and while well played (by Bradley Cooper) the chracter is not really believable.  Assaulting his boss was over the top and totally unrealistic.  The many flashbacks are confusing but eventually you begin to piece together what is going on.  Nevertheless the movie is rather slow even though the double and triple crosses leave you wondering what is going on. However, as the plot moves to conclusion the action picks up as you find that you shouldn't try to con a conman.  The ending is totally unexpected but when you get there you realize that that was the only logical conclusion.  For me this was somewhat of a morality play because some of the characters were really trying to do the right thing using the wrong way.  This is a good film and while the screenplay was only so-so, the actors did a very good job and Christian Bale (Irving) could get an academy nomination.

A little too long IMO but I had a great time. This cast is perfect! If I could, I would just have them in every movie from now on... A lot have been said already about the performances but seeing these guys in action is just so much fun. Can you believe that Christian Bale was Batman? I'm seriously considering buying this DVD - and I never buy movies...

"The art of survival is a story that never ends." Irving Rosenfeld (Bale) is a con-man who works low level scams but makes a killing. One night at a party he meets a woman named Sydney Prosser (Adams) and his life is changed. He not only finds a new lover but also a new partner. When she sets up a deal that goes bad they are forced to work for the FBI or spend their lives in jail. The opening of the movie states that "some of this actually happened" so this isn't really a true story just as a heads up. I wanted to see this movie for one reason...the cast. The cast in this is amazing and how can a movie with this cast be bad? The answer to that slowly revealed itself as I watched. It boiled down to the fact that none of the characters were really like-able at all and because of that I felt no connection to any of them. The cardinal sin for any movie is for the watcher not to be involved in the characters lives, if you don't care about them then it doesn't matter what happens in the movie. That is how I felt watching this. Bale did a great job in this but I found it really hard to get into the movie and couldn't find anyone to root for or even care for. That fact alone brought down the enjoyment of the movie and when it ended I was very disappointed by what I saw. Overall, a big disappointment, especially with this cast. Not worthy of the best picture nomination at all. I disappointingly give this a B-.

I know Jennifer Lawrence is a supporting role but she was just so incredible every time she was on with her "husband" Christian Bale, or her son or her boyfriend.  As odd as the rest of the cast was, she was a full blown character from Mars. She just grabs hold of that camera when she comes onscreen and never lets go. Amy Adams was sexier and more sophisticated in the movie but she did not create the indelible impression on me which Lawrence did. Bale was wholly unrecognizable as a pudgy Jewish conman who becomes more likable as the film goes on. Bradley Cooper as the FBI man and Louis C.K. as his boss were good but again these were not roles you will never forget.

this is a film about con men and women plus the feds trying to act the same.  they are trying to take down some politicians. the con people are in it to get out of a jail sentence. we have seen con based movies before. The plot all revolves around tricking people until you can't tell who is tricking whom. it all gets ironed out in the end but it is the performances which make this kind of movie. we already have seen the basic plot so our socks have to be knocked out by the cast.  And they were.

Bale and Lawrence were such a great comic duo together that they should try it again together. They have real screen chemistry.  He had a lot of romance chemistry with Adams but the laugh out loud comedy he did with Lawrence is much harder to achieve.

Jeremy Renner also did a great job as Carmine, the politician with the heart of gold (talk about pulling off a real long shot!).

American Hustle is a crime comedy-drama film loosely based on the FBI ABSCAM operation of the late 1970s and early '80s. It stars Christian Bale and Amy Adams as two con artists who are forced by an FBI agent (Bradley Cooper) to set up an elaborate sting operation on corrupt politicians, including the mayor of Camden, New Jersey (Jeremy Renner). Jennifer Lawrence plays the unpredictable wife of Bale's character.

Its hard to believe in the relationship or any chemistry between Irving (Christian Bale) and Sydney (Amy Adams). They seem to be people who would never genuinely attracted to one another. Sydney appears to be too sophisticated to have any true feelings. Irving's wife Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence) seems to be so disrespectful of him that its hard to believe the lengths she goes to keep (?) him. Lawrence compensates for her Rosalyn's character flaws with unbridled energy but her emotional outbursts and screaming wears annoyingly on the nerves.

Bradley Cooper's performance of the FBI fluctuates between blind self-assuredness and insecure cockiness. It becomes entertaining to watch his character get his comeuppance.

In the film, Camden mayor Carmine Polito is shown as a selfless politician who gets involved in the scam to provide jobs to his constituents but its unrealistic that a person such as Irving would go to the lengths he goes to for Carmine.

The sheik scene is so fruitless in that it doesn't seem that it would have ever been believable. It all seemed to be a build-up to something that never came.

American Hustle is a unceremonious exploration of the lengths to which people are willing to go to "create" their "life." Sometimes the Hustle seems to be the dance the film makes in genre. The artistic choices are very interesting. Sometimes its a drama; sometimes dark comedy; that takes turns into elements of movie musical.

In the opening credits, you're told: "some of this actually happened".

From there, the director draws you into a story of deception. In the opening scene, you watch as the principal character (Christian Bale) carefully works on his hair- elaborately covering up his baldness.

This is but the first deception. As the story unfolds, there is more and more elaborate deception and intrigue. It's a clever and intelligent story- a black comedy and cautionary tale.

Besides the clever story, the 1970s setting is recreated with care- and the soundtrack includes some excellent music from the era.

The cast is uniformly excellent- and they play their deceptive roles well.

A story well told- and a movie worth seeing.

Watch for the uncredited cameo appearance of Robert de Niro.

Revised: February 3, 2014

Those viewers with long memories might notice resemblances between David OI. Russell's film and George Roy Hill's THE STING.  In both works, the principal center of attention is on the psychology of conning; how people can render themselves perfectly plausible to their victims and get away with it.  However there is one important difference: whereas the earlier film took a jokey approach to the subject-matter (complete with Scott Joplin-inspired ragtime score), AMERICAN HUSTLE takes a long hard look at the lives of Irving Rosenfeld (Christian Bale) and sidekick Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams), and shows how their lives are fundamentally empty.  Although Rosenfeld protests his enduring love for his wife Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence), it's clear that his main focus of attention is on sustaining the con.  When it threatens to get out of hand, he tries to withdraw, but finds himself unable to do so.  Likewise Sydney; although she is a masterly impersonator of a British aristocrat, she has nothing much else to fall back on.  In the world of late 70s New York, it is every person for themselves - even the cop Richie DiMasso (Bradley Cooper) is out to exploit everyone around him.  In the end, Irving and Sydney come to a decision - the only way to extricate themselves from difficulty is to plan the ultimate con.  Their lives will not improve as a result, but at least they will be safe for a while.  AMERICAN HUSTLE is a long, controlled, brilliantly acted movie.  Director Russell's camera focuses on the protagonists in minute detail, taking a long hard look at their relationships, while suggesting that such relationships only work if the con works successfully.  If the con fails, then relationships come crashing down.  The late Seventies New York atmosphere is brilliantly evoked; the city is both attractive yet terribly seedy, a place where only the fittest survive.  The soundtrack, with hits from the period, only serves to enhance this mood.  This film has been nominated for several awards, and justifiably so.

I tried watching this movie with my eyes open. I tried watching it with them shut. I dozed through part of it. Yet nothing helped me make sense of what was going on. The script is just appallingly bad. The start of the film doesn't represent the start of the events portrayed in the movie, but we don't know that, so the sense of bewildered confusion sets in right away. From what I can gather American Hustle is about a small time con merchant (Christian Bale) who hooks up with another con merchant (Amy Adams) to fleece various gullible folk. The FBI pounces and yet with startling speed, the agent handling the case decides to use Bale and Adams to entrap a local mayor he thinks is corrupt. The story is based very loosely on the Abscam scandal of the late 1970s and I wish it had stuck to the facts, since they can't have been as confusing as this mess. The plot lurches back and forth and turns into The Sting with a fake Arab sheikh for a few minutes before returning to mass confusion. The acting is actually pretty good but it is fatally undermined by the script.

American Hustle follows on director David O. Russells Silver Linings Playbook that proved to be a hit last year in 2012. American Hustle is more a madcap comedy as we follow two con artists Irving Rosenfeld (Christian Bale) and Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams) in the late 1970s. Irving and Sydney are kindred spirits and deeply attracted to each other, as they play off of Irvings business loan scam where he takes $5,000 from his clients and gives nothing back. He also sells art forgeries on the side to which Sydney adds some class by affecting a British accent and turning herself into Lady Edith Greensly. Sydney eventually discovers that Irving is married to a flaky blond named Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence) and the two women despise each other.  All is going remarkably well until Irving and Sydney are caught scamming by an FBI agent named Richie DiMaso (Bradley Cooper).

Richie is not the sharpest tool in the shed gets wrapped up in Irvings stories on how he conned people. Richie thinks that in the post Watergate 70s he can make a name for himself by setting a trap for unwary crooked politicians. Only he needs Irving and Sydney as players to pull his scheme off. Richie picks the mayor of Atlantic City Carmine Polito as his victim, who needs to rebuild his city to get people into a newly built casino.  When bribery fails to lure Polito into Richies trap and Arab investor is invented and Abscam is born. Little by little, the scam becomes more complicated until the mob gets interested.

American Hustle is fun to watch because one never knows what is coming next, and everyone is conning someone else. Christian Bale is excellent as Irving, someone who could convince you that its in your interest to hand over all of your money to him. He fits into the 70s fashion with his hair piece and comb over hiding his bald head and his loud shirts and trade mark neckerchief. Amy Adams personifies the post-1960s "liberated woman, with her loose filling clothing and lack of underwear. Her clothing gives Sydney a liberated and bold appearance that fits her character well. Jennifer Lawrence is wonderful as Irvings manipulative wife, throwing insults at Sydney when they meet and almost blowing the scam by spilling some of the details to a mobster.  Bradley Cooper does a great job playing the ambitious but over reactive FBI agent who can barely control himself when it comes to ordering his boss to give him more money for the scam.  It was also good to see veteran actor Anthony Zerbe as Senator Horton Mitchell, brief as his part was.
American Hustle is a brilliant caper film that keeps you guessing and has some very fine performances by a fantastic cast.
This was a great movie from beginning to end, each part seemed tailor made for these great actors. This will be one of my go to movies when I need some real entertainment.
I love it when a mainstream Hollywood movie offers both entertainment as well as doesn't insult your intelligence. Good fun, good acting, a entertaining plot and dialogue.

I loved this movie and was fooled for a while by Bradley Cooper's role.  All the characters were stars and deserve awards.
I can't wait to see it again and will order the dvd.

three quarters of the way through I would have left if I was alone.  Boring.

Jennifer Lawrence - never boring though. And Christian Bale does a very good job

Suppose you want to see a movie about World War Two. But World War Two is kind of boring, isn't it? We had better jazz it up. How about this: Adolf Hitler (Christian Bale) is really an alien - and FDR (Bradley Cooper) is a robot - and Eleanor Roosevelt (Amy Adams, who needs no makeup for this role) is having an affair with Empress Nariko (Jennifer Lawrence). If you think that's a great idea for a movie then I guarantee you will love American Hustle.
Every film has something in it that doesn't make sense. But this one lays it on with a trowel.
Bale's and Adams' characters are conducting a finance scam. You give them thousands and they promise to loan you tens of thousands. This is not a Ponzi scheme - which would involve investments, not loans. It could only work if the con artists vanish as soon as they get your money. But these two stick around, have a real office, and intend to do this indefinitely. In other words, it makes no sense whatsoever.
When they are arrested, the FBI wants their help because they are "experts" on running a con. Go figure.
It gets worse.
Adams' character talks with an "English accent" which comes and goes - and would be convincing if your idea of the West End of London is Camden, New Jersey. Her FBI handler does not know who she is, even though he earlier arrested and kept her in a cell for days. Despite this lapse of basic police proceedure, the FBI trusts her and her boyfriend with two million dollars of taxpayer money. (I hope nobody from al Qaida is reading this.)
Adams is supposed to make targets of the scam think she is a London banker. Only if British banks staff themselves with Las Vegas hookers would it make sense as to why Adams wears an open blouse apparently glued to her nipples.
If you can swallow all this, then you should also have no problem with the scene where an FBI agent pummels his superior and the assault is regarded as just a merry prank.
I give this film two stars only because of Jennifer Lawrence, who is a national treasure. But having her here is like keeping the family jewels in a trash bag.

To be honest I found this film a little manic at first, but once I was hooked, I was hooked. Cristian Bale and Amy Adams(I'll stick to using the actors names it's easier) are two con-artists caught in a scheme by Earnest FBI agent  Bradley Cooper. They are promised impunity in exchange for bigger fish.  This is where things take off in a plot with many twists and turns and many unforgettable characters. In the process, Cooper falls for Adams believing she is British if not an aristocrat, which she claims. They launch a scheme involving payoff to the mayor of Camden, NJ and many key Washington politicians. Jennifer Lawrence makes a brilliant job of playing Bales unsteady, slightly mad wife. This film reminded me of the brilliant film The Grifters of 1990, but iseven more clever, and often hysterically funny.

If you have problems falling asleep, watch American Hustle. A lot of people are finding it to be better than a sleeping pill.

The plot is hard to follow. The whole thing feels staged and fake. Scenes go on for way too long. The movie seems cheap like a poor man's Goodfellas, only that was a great movie.

Ignore all the critical acclaim and oscar nominations. The director of this movie directed two good movies - The Fighter and Silver Lining's Playbook, so the critics are like - this must be good, right? They got hustled.

Don't waste your money.
When I want to leave to make popcorn you know it's just not a great film. Loved the music but who didn't adore the 70's. Yes, the acting was worthy of the awards, just a boring film.

Anticipation for American Hustle for myself at least, was off the radar. I really do need to stop putting such high expectations on movies and just watch them for the enjoyment. So today, I will talk about American Hustle.

American Hustle introduces us to Irving. Now Irving is not just your average typical man living in the 1970s, no no no Irving is a con man. And even though Irving is married to Rossalyn with whom he shares a son Danny, he is having an affair with a woman "Edith" who coincidentally enough is also a con artist. While things are going good for Irving and ''Edith'', their schemes are soon halted by a man Richie DiMaso who is not actually a con man but is actually a FBI agent. In exchange for freedom he commissions Irving and "Edith" to help him set up some arrests and just like that we have our movie.

For the most part, American Hustle was everything I hoped it would be. I laughed a lot(in a good way) during the movie, mostly at Jennifer Lawrence's character Rossalyn. It is no surprise she was nominated. Bradley Cooper sports quite the hairstyle but he does his job well as Richie DiMaso. Amy Adams was stellar as our con artist "Edith". And Christian Bale shows why he is nominated for his role as our main character Irving.

To keep my review short, I would honestly say that American Hustle is a Good not Great movie. I did not expect to feel that way going into this movie, but I would not call this movie great. Still, I cannot call American Hustle a bad movie. The story line is interesting (and be prepared to laugh) and the overall setup of the movie itself was nicely done. Nowhere near the greatness I expected, but American Hustle gets rated

4 Stars
