*** This review may contain spoilers ***

David O. Russell, now a shining light in the American film industry, has returned after his recent success with "Silver Linings Playbook'. His new entry for the Oscar competition is 'American Hustle', which is loosely based on the ABSCAM scandals of the late 70s and early 80s.

Russell's new picture aspires to be an updated 'Goodfellas'; except here, the protagonists are not Mafiosi but low-rent con artists. The story begins slowly as a narrator fills in the background of the story's anti-hero, Irving Rosenfeld - part legitimate owner of a couple of dry cleaning establishments out on Long Island and part unsavory loan shark and middleman for art forgers. Christian Bale as Rosenfeld does the most convincing job of the principal actors in conveying just how this petty criminal fell from grace (notably Bale gained fifty pounds for the role).

Less successful is Amy Adams, who plays Sydney Prosser, Rosenfeld's con artist girlfriend who pretends to be a British aristocrat ('Lady Edith Greensley'). There's just something about Adams that prevents me (no matter how hard she tries) from believing that she can play the role of a true 'bad girl' (others, of course, are free to disagree).

The break into Act Two occurs when the FBI catches Irving and Sydney perpetuating one of their loan scams and forces them to help flush out four new marks. Sydney wants to flee the country, but Irving refuses, since he's still married and has a young son. As it turns out, the film's antagonist really is Richie, played by an over-the- top Bradley Cooper - a belligerent FBI agent, who continually pressures Irving to cooperate and browbeats his own boss to accept some of his far-fetched plans.

Russell has been quoted as saying that he concentrated more on the characters' stories, rather than the overall plot. Nonetheless, a good deal of the dialogue is improvised and I found many of the interpersonal scenes to be unnecessarily drawn out (Jennifer Lawrence has little to do as Rosalyn, Irving's over emotional wife, who eventually comes to accept that Irving is no longer attracted to her).

Many of the principals' machinations are supposed to be comic in natureparticularly those of Richie, who at one point slugs his boss in the face with a telephone. Ritchie reminds me of Cooper's character in 'Silver Linings', who also can't control his temper.

Unfortunately, it's really the 'Hustle' story itself that leaves quite a bit to be desired. It's a story virtually devoid of any high stakes. The whole idea of course is that this is a story of low stakesand we're supposed to feel bemused by the characters' pettiness. But much of the pettiness simply isn't very compelling at all.

We have such low moments in Act II, as Sydney convinces the FBI secretary to make the $2 million unauthorized wire transfer and then Richie's boss' boss, Amado inexplicably green lights Richie's escapades. The bulk of the machinations involve Richie's quest to entrap Polito, the corrupt Camden, New Jersey mayor. The closest we get to high drama is when Polito brings Irving's fake sheik to a casino party, where they end up meeting a real mobster, Victor Tellegio, a former Meyer Lansky associate played by Robert DeNiro. Tellegio tries to outfox the 'sheik' by speaking Arabic, but Irving's friend turns the tables by showing that he knows Arabic too.

The rest of 'American Hustle' is anti-climactic. With the Camden mayor's assistance, a number of Congressmen are taken down, after they accept bribes. The big 'twist' at the end is too little and too late. It's not necessary to reveal the ending, but suffice it to say that the FBI's plan to fry some bigger fish, goes awry.

I'm not sure whether it was that I didn't really care too much about the principals and their back stories, or whether the twists and turns in the plot amounted to nothing more than 'small potatoes'. I do know that the film's Hollywood happy ending has nothing to do with what happened in real life (the wife committed suicide and the mistress divorced Mel Weinberg, Irving's real-life prototype, and no longer talks to him).

If there's anything good to say about this film, it has more to do with the re-creation of the late 70s era, replete with all those golden oldies on the soundtrack. It's too bad that most of the characters here never rise above the level of caricature.

The subjects of the real hustle appear to have been all those critics, who lapped up this overrated cinematic sleight of hand, in their desperate desire to discover a new Scorsese-like auteur.

After reading critics reviews and listening to friends I really tried to like this movie, however the four of us who went to see this movie all agreed it was the most boring nonsensical movie we had ever seen. We just didn't get it, and maybe thought there were actually two movies made with the same name, and we picked the bad one.

Knowing the pedigree of a movie, not only who the stars are, but who the director is, who the writers are, can easily help us separate the mutts from the pure breeds in the movie world. And if the pedigree is one of huge prior success of many of these elements then that augurs well for the success of this movie.

David O Russell directed the highly regarded The Fighter from two years ago which secured 7 Academy Award nominations, Academy Awards for Christian Bale and Melissa Leo,and a nomination for Amy Adams.

He wrote and directed Silver Linings Playbook one of the outstanding movies of 2011/12, which secured an Academy Award for Jennifer Lawrence last year, and a total of four acting nominations including Bradley Cooper and Robert De Niro, and nominations for Best Picture, Best Director, and Best Adapted Screenplay.

American Hustle reunites Russell, De Niro, Bale, Lawrence and Adams from these previous two hits, and continues the outstanding pedigree displayed in those movies.

Loosely based on the 1970s Abscam scandal, this is a multi-layered entertaining movie, involving a con man and his mistress, played by Bale and Adams, an emotionally tempestuous wife played by Jennifer Lawrence, organized crime elements represented by De Niro and others, and law enforcement interests played by Bradley Cooper.

I remember an interview Amy Adams gave two years where she complained that a journalist wrote that she did not have a sexual image at which she took great umbrage. Perhaps this was due to characters she played such as the Princess in Enchanted, or the nun in Doubt. She lays that particular criticism to rest in this movie playing a very sexual character, who wears skin clinging outfits, and no bra, ever. This all works to create a very alluring persona, and so she really pushes the envelope in this movie. I think her performance is the most memorable and nuanced of all the actors. Bale's character has a glued on comb over and that hairy thing does not fool anyone.

The other memorable performance that distinguishes this movie is that of Jennifer Lawrence. Two scenes in particular, one where she and her husbands mistress have a confrontation with an interesting turn. Very amusing.
The other a spectacularly messed up scene which I call the 'power of intention,' scene which had the whole theater laughing and for me was worth the price of admission. Another scene where she intensely lip-syncs I also found highly amusing.

Amy Adams has been nominated for Academy Awards four times for Junebug, Doubt, The Fighter , and The Master, without winning yet. Maybe this will be her year. I think she has shown great variety and ability in her roles. I particularly liked her turn as a rough tough warrior type role in The Fighter.

One thing that can be said for David O Russell, he knows how to write good roles for actors as all the acting nominations indicate. American Hustle has been nominated for seven Golden Globe awards, which augurs well for its Oscar ambitions.

American Hustle opened in limited release in the USA on December 13th 2013, achieving a highly impressive $76,000,000 in only three weeks of release. The movies most likely to win awards are mostly released in December perfectly timed for awards season, and this is definitely a cut above most movies you will see this year with some highly memorable scenes.

I think most people will love it, and I hope this was helpful.

Most Hollywood films celebrate working class values and no film does that better this year than AMERICAN HUSTLE. What's weird about this movie though is that neither of the characters who are trying to do good are rewarded but both of the hustlers get exactly what they want: each other. Neither the Bale or Adams characters are loyal to their class (they'll hustle anyone) but they are ultimately loyal to each other. Bale is maybe the more sympathetic character (his schemes are just about money but he really doesn't want to hurt anyone) but the Adams character is far more mysterious, she hustles people not just for money but to prove something to herself -- to prove to herself that life is not determined by the accident of birth or class affiliation. Her roles are opportunities to explore her sexuality, intellect, imagination, and sense of play. To her the real is not some stable property/commodity with a fixed value but whatever you believe it is and get others to believe it is. Although the film like most other Hollywood films praises working class types, it undermines the notion that working class types are one-dimensional and/or incapable of participating not just in the American dream of social mobility but the even more compelling dream of identity mobility. Director David O Russell is clearly on the side of the working class and he loves showing working class types enjoying working class pleasures but in American Hustle he adds at least one new pleasure to the working class repertoir: the joy of conning people from the upper classes. At the beginning of the film Bale and Adams will con anyone regardless of class but by the end of the film they have affirmed their class loyalty and only after doing this do they seem to understand themselves and to be as merry if not as socialist as Robin Hood. American Hustle does play like a Scorsese film with one important difference: the racketeering raconteurs in America Hustle actually find a way to go legitimate (or at least as legitimate as any Modern "artist" can be). So what you have in American Hustle is the first existentially complex working class con dramedy. I'd give it a Globe.

This movie is a confused mess.  Having seen great con movies like The Sting, this will leave you significantly underwhelmed.  Most of it doesn't make much sense, especially around how their ongoing con business works - they talk about upgrading to a nicer office in a permanent location? What is stopping someone that they ripped off from coming back and getting their money back?

The characters are surprisingly flat and one-dimensional despite the good actors and actresses involved. I think they tried the best to make it work but the screenplay is so immature it's like a kid wrote it.  Every thought and motivation is broadcast across the characters' faces.  Not something you'd expect from con artists.  Whoever is backing this writer/director really must be just into looks without substance because a lot of detail went into the costume and setting which came across looking good.  Shame that it still doesn't make the actual core story any better or more watchable.

American Hustle is a disappointing chaotic and beautiful mess of a film with a plot that becomes convoluted with every con, twist and turn, and by the end you won't care about the plot, and leave the theater wondering what you just watched. American Hustle is thankfully saved by the excellent cast, and the eclectic cast of characters in the film.

Yes I was a little disappointed with American Hustle, and the overall plot of the film. Thankfully what makes American Hustle such a good film are the actors and cast of characters. Christian Bale stars as Irving Rosenfeld a small time business man who owns a few dry cleaners, but makes most of his money as a con artist. The character is balding, overweight with heart problems, but doesn't let his limitations stop him from getting what he wants. It was a welcome change to see Bale in such a different role from the suave good looking dark knight Bruce Wayne, and Bale again shines as Rosenfeld. Just like Rosenfeld, Sydney Prosser is determined to escape her old miserable life as a stripper into Edith Greensly. Amy Adams is superb playing the dangerous, sexy, and complicated Sydney. While Rosenfeld and Prosser find love together a con artist is a con artist and will con even the people he or she loves like having an adopted son, and Rosalyn Rosenfeld a stay at home unhinged wife who is terrified of change. Now Lawrence was funny playing the fierce Rosalyn with raw and primal energy, and Rosalyn slowly grows throughout the film, but it wasn't Lawrence's best performance of her career, and not her best performance this year. Still even with it not being her best performance Lawrence still shines throughout the film, and is worthy of an Oscar nomination.

As for the rest of the cast the majority of them gave good performances. Michael Pea was great playing a FBI agent who poses as Sheik Abdullah, and Robert De Niro was splendid in his brief role as Victor Tellegio. The only questionable acting choice or character in American Hustle was Jeremy Renner as Mayor Carmine Polito. While I like Renner, and know the character was necessary in the plot for Irving to come to some realizations the actor and character just didn't seem to fit, and left the role lacking throughout the film. I am somewhat divided on Richard DiMaso and actor Bradley Cooper. I know director David O. Russell loves to bring out the dark and crazy side of his characters displaying to the world that we're all have a few screws loose, but Russell and Cooper to DiMaso to the extreme as the FBI agent entraps Irving, and Sydney forcing them to help him nap other criminals. While at times laughed and really enjoyed Cooper playing the ambitious DiMaso the character could at times be off-putting and just plain annoying, but with the quality of acting, and Russell's directing these small flaws didn't keep me from enjoying the film.

I guess I should speak briefly about the plot as that was what I had the biggest problem with while watching American Hustle. The film is very loosely based on events in the 1970's, and written by Eric Warren Singer and David O. Russell. The plot involving DiMaso using Irving, and Sydney to get an ever growing number of politician and criminals becomes more convoluted as the stakes get higher, and everyone is conning, and using each other to get what they desire out of the situation. That plot drags on for too long, and by the end I just didn't care about that part of the story, and if you look at it that way, and just focus on the great cast of characters, and how the plot is there for the characters to evolve grow, and change than the story does work.

David O. Russell is at his best crafting great characters, and bringing out the best in his actors as he has done in Silver Linings Playbook, Three Kings, and The Fighter, and continues to do so here with American Hustle. There is something I've noticed with his directing. Russell loves writing flawed and slightly unhinged characters as well as dipping his feet into the darkness of those said characters yet never truly submerging into the darkness which I enjoy, and continues to do so here with American Hustle. Russell could have easily taken a darker turn with the film, but wanted to display people's ability to change, and grow showing everyone has hope for the future no matter how messed up they are, and I enjoy that about Russell. If there was a flaw to his directing of American Hustle it would be in his writing, and how he put the film together, but I believe what we got was Russell's attention all along, and it just didn't work completely on film, and again that was a small complaint to Russell great directing job in American Hustle.

American Hustle does disappoint in the story department most likely keeping the film from being nominated or being a serious contender for best picture award at the Oscars, American Hustle certainly doesn't disappoint in every other department from an excellent cast that includes Amy Adams, Christian Bale, Robert De Niro, Jennifer Lawrence, and Bradly Cooper where Lawrence, Adams, and Bale are the crowning jewels giving Oscar worth performances to the wonderful out of this world characters that spring to life as well as the music, and top not directing by David O. Russell making American Hustle a film that shouldn't be missed

I can honestly say that American Hustle is one of the best movies of the year. This film had an amazing plot line of deceit and false promises. I'll be frank, seeing Bradley Cooper finally play a loser made me feel a little better about myself as well. The main characters all have such strong personalities that clash incredibly well together. The story is told from a start at the end and go back to the beginning sort of perspective that really works for this movie. Hustling is such a common thing that we overlook in our society, but it happens every day. American Hustle explores what it is like to actually hustle for a living and what the consequences are when you are caught.

Irving (Christian Bale)is a con artist. His wife (Jennifer Lawrence) is flaky so he has a mistress Edith (Amy Adams) who helps him in his cons. When she gets pinched by an eager FBI agent (Bradley Cooper as Richie) they are asked to assist the FBI with four arrests and then they would be let go. Irving reluctantly agrees and Edith helps against her better judgement. The plot leads us to Irving being involved in a bust of organized crime figures (Robert De Niro), something that would lead to his demise and that of everyone he loves. He is in over his head. During the film you know everyone is scheming, but who is going to come out on top?

This is another classic con artist tale. It is a crime/thriller/drama/comedy. The acting was superb which made the script look substandard. Amy Irving is perhaps the sexist we have seen her to date. I never miss a film with Jennifer Lawrence who proclaims "Thank God for me." Her role starts out minor but then grows. The ladies room kiss with Amy Adams is something I predict will be on loop.

Seems like a good old fashion con artist film with some fine acting.

Parental Guide: F-bombs. Brief sex. No nudity. Stripper with pasties, most likely Amy Adams body double as face is not shown with nearly bare torso.

I had been looking forward to seeing American Hustle since it was announced. I almost saw it on release day, but I have an aversion to watching movies with people who are more concerned with noisily eating their weight in popcorn than watching what is on the screen. Yesterday's viewing was still pretty packed, but I am glad I didn't wait any longer. The movie is a lot of fun.

There's something a little jarring about David O. Russell's movies. I think it's the amount of conflict present between his characters. Have you ever been to a party or a gathering where people are all talking at once? It can be chaotic. There might be little gems of information hidden in the cacophony, but it's easy to miss. If you have seen The Fighter, you'll know that Russell's characters were often at each others throats. In Silver Linings Playbook, the central romance wasn't fully realized until the participants had survived numerous arguments. American Hustle feels similar in many ways to both those movies, although the canvas is broader and more colorful.

The movie opens with the statement, "Some of this actually happened." Well, the 1970s certainly happened, but I doubt that many people resembled the main characters in this story. The opening scene sets the tone by showing Irving Rosenfeld (Christian Bale) fixing his hair. This is an elaborate process involving glue and a comb-over. IMDB states that Bale gained more than 40 pounds to play the role, and herniated two discs while perfecting his slouching posture. It's quite a transformation. That opening scene is a clear statement that American Hustle is not going to be a serious drama, and the movie rarely deviates from that initial statement of intent.

Rosenfeld is an interesting character. He spends most of his time conning people out of their money, promising loans for those who can make a down payment of $5,000. He meets Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams) at a party and the two form a partnership and are attracted to each other. The plot becomes more complicated when an intended mark turns out to be FBI agent Richie DiMaso (Bradley Cooper). To avoid going to jail, Rosenfeld and Prosser agree to help DiMaso convict four corrupt officials, starting with Mayor Carmine Polito (Jeremy Renner).

What follows is a complete mess. Does Rosenfeld really love Prosser? Will he ever leave his wife Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence)? Is Prosser in love with Rosenfeld, DiMaso, both, or neither? The story contains a delightful cameo from another Russell regular, a science oven, a fake sheikh, great music from the 70s, fantastic performances from the main cast, twists, humor, intrigue, and plenty of laughs. Is it coherent? Not completely on the first viewing. Is it worth seeing? Absolutely.

Jennifer Lawrence isn't in many scenes, but she's fascinating every time she appears. Bale and Adams dominate most of the story, and are ably supported by Bradley Cooper, who has become a much better actor than I once imagined. It's interesting to see these Russell favorites make fun of themselves. Lawrence is borderline crazy, Bale almost unrecognizable, Adams more manipulative than most of her former characters, and Cooper willing to act like a fool. Is this the sort of chemistry that develops when directors continually use actors that they have worked with in the past? I love seeing directors such as Lynch, the Coens, Darabont and Tarantino going back to the same actors repeatedly. I think it adds something to the performances.

Like a Tarantino movie, American Hustle is more about style and the journey than the actual plot. It's simply fun to watch these characters interact. Don't expect a clever scam along the lines of The Sting. Just enjoy the wild ride. I already can't wait to see it again, despite its imperfections. I have a feeling that I will end up loving the movie once I have allowed it to sink in and with repeat viewings. The same was true for Silver Linings Playbook and Jason Reitman's Young Adult.

If you're perceptive and still reading, you might have noticed that I haven't talked much about the plot. This is one you need to experience without knowing too much going in. If you're a fan a Russell, or the main actors, you'll come away with a smile on your face. If you're not, this movie might just convert you.

For now, the overall score is 4/5.

"American Hustle" is a laugh-out-loud funny, very clever, well-produced, well-acted movie about conmen, crooked politicians, and an FBI sting operation. I enjoyed it while I was watching it but it left me empty. I didn't care about any of the characters or the plot points. I wasn't rooting for anybody and I wasn't involved in anything. Ultimately "American Hustle" felt been-there-done-that to me, and gimmicky and shallow. It reminded me of a lot of previous films about lovable gangsters and conmen, like "Goodfellas," "The Sting," and "Guys and Dolls." Christian Bale as petty conman Irving Rosenfeld reminded me of Frank Sinatra as Nathan Detroit.

The gimmicks begin as the movie opens. It opens on a shot of Christian Bale's fat and bloated stomach. Bale is famous for losing weight for his role in "The Machinist." Then he became buff and muscular for "Batman." For "American Hustle" Christian Bale gave himself a fat gut. His fat gut takes up about thirty seconds of screen time and Bale could have played the role without it. His gut took me out of the movie. I started thinking, not about the character or the plot, but about Bale's tendency to gain or lose weight for roles. I assume he's pushing for an Oscar. I felt manipulated.

The plot is pretty pointless. A small time conman, Irving (Christian Bale) and his conwoman girlfriend Sydney / Edith (Amy Adams) are recruited by FBI agent Richie (Bradley Cooper) to snag crooked politicians, including the mayor of Camden Carmine Polito (Jeremy Renner). Irving's wife Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence) gets in the way and causes some comic mayhem. Robert DeNiro shows up as a dangerous Mafioso.

The production values are very high. The costumes are outrageous: velvet tuxedos and open shirts revealing hairy chests and gold chains. Amy Adams and Jennifer Lawrence are all decked out and paraded like models. In "Night at the Museum 2" Amy Adams wore tight, flesh-colored jodhpurs. Everyone talks about her butt in that movie. In "American Hustle" she wears plunging necklines and slit skirts. Everyone will be talking about her breasts and legs.

The direction is fluid and musical  you feel like you're on an amusing ride. 1970s pop hits make up the soundtrack and action is choreographed to fit the music.

The movie is laugh-out-loud funny, funnier than some films billed as comedies. It's hard to tell what genre the film is meant to be, because there are scenes where characters are obviously in pain.

The audience is conned as well as the characters onscreen. There is a surprise. The surprise felt pretty cheap to me. The surprise was executed not by cleverness, but simply by hiding information from the audience.

The performances are all fun to watch and very strong. Problem for me was that each performance seemed to exist in its own world. Christian Bale is doing comedy and parody. He is mocking the character he plays, and low class conmen in general. Jennifer Lawrence is weak. She is pretty, pouty, and young, but I didn't catch any acting talent. Bradley Cooper, as the FBI agent, is intense and grating in his hyper ambition and lack of smarts and caution. His character never came together for me, never achieved any coherence.

Amy Adams is the heart of the movie. She is fiercely intelligent, deadly, really, in her amorality and her love for her man. The real standout is Jeremy Renner as Camden, NJ, mayor Carmine Polito. Renner is from a completely straight, serious movie. He comes across not as an actor playing a role, but as the "real" Carmine Polito, though Polito is a fictional character based on former Camden mayor Angelo Errichetti.

"American Hustle" depicts conflict between straight, square people who tell the truth and con artists who lie, cheat and steal. As is often the case in Hollywood films, "American Hustle" comes down firmly on the side of con artists. "Everybody's a con artist!" the film wants you to believe. "Everybody lies, cheats, and steals!" Hollywood would take this stance because Hollywood manufactures illusions.

"American Hustle" alters history to make this position believable. "American Hustle" becomes heavy-handed in its insistence on manipulating its audience into liking two characters and disliking a third. Camden's mayor was not the saint the film wants you to think he was, and the real Irving didn't do the kindly things the film depicts him as doing. Camden, NJ, is a horrible place to live. Its population is shrinking. It ranks first in violent crime. Political corruption is rampant. In making a saint out of the mayor of Camden, David O. Russell sticks his Hollywood finger in the eye of New Jersey's poor and crime victims.

"American Hustle" is a drama comedy genre film set in the late 1970s. The narrative mainly follows con artists Irving Rosenfeld (Christian Bale) and Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams) and their money making scams, but also the excessive desire of FBI Agent Richie Di Maso (Jeremy Renner) to stamp out white collar crime.

The colourful, vice ridden lifestyle of crooks Rosenfeld and Prosser provides the viewer with several interesting scenes, and the river of deception causes Rosenfeld to be constantly juggling all his dodgy personal and business enterprises, which is a regular source of viewer entertainment. But the storyline also exposes the so-called good guys as corruptible in their own ways, which ultimately places them a step or two behind the seasoned cheats. Seeing into the calamity of all their lives it becomes clear falseness is a currency they all trade in to try and get what they want from people, and may the best swindler win.

The costume, hairstyles and set designs masterfully capture the era, and an exceptional cast enables several twisted personalities to shine.

Nicholas R.W. Henning - Australian Author

Filthy, immense personalities with a shared lack of moral compass own the driver's seat in this lingering peek at a late-'70s government sting operation and the flawed individuals caught up in its net. While the titular hustle is, obviously, the driving force behind this film's plot, the lion's share of its effort is spent inspecting the players themselves, rendering each from a variety of different angles and lights. In fact, the first two acts concentrate almost exclusively on the cast, to the detriment of the heist itself - which isn't necessarily a bad thing, just a different approach than I'd  expected. Of course, that ratio is flipped on its head in time for the climax, when our slick set of con (wo)men abruptly realize they're in way over their heads and the audience lets out a collective gasp; "Oh, crap." Predictably, the A-list actors hit all of their notes with sly ease, with the best - Christian Bale and Jennifer Lawrence - completely disappearing into their roles. Poor Bale has transformed his body in this way so many times over the years - an enormous gut, meticulously bad combover and slumped posture epitomize this particular role - that it's hard to imagine he won't pay a steep price later in life. A few scenes are slower than they need to be, and the focus could stand to be a touch sharper, but without both indulgences this wouldn't be the film it is.

Writer/director David O. Russell is quickly making a name for himself, and after seeing this movie, there'll be no letting up on the buzz he's creating.

Here's the scoop. Irving Rosenberg (Christian Bale) has a few small businesses in Jersey but he also dabbles in small time cons. He meets Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams) who is looking to changer her life. They up the con game together but get stung by FBI guy Richie DiMaso (Bradley Cooper) who holds them ransom so they can provide him with cons involving much bigger fish. They agree but all might be in over their heads in this game and it all gets really messy.

This has it all. It has a great script. I would need to view it again to untangle all the cons and schemes but it's smart to a "T." The script also gives us great characters who are played tremendously well by an equally great cast. There are no confusing these folks. Each is distinct. And each has an agenda. How far will they go to get what they want? Who's playing who? It has great direction. Russell always seems to know where to put the camera and made certain his set designers, wardrobe folk et al gave this a right on look of mid 70s New Jersey.

Back to the actors. Christian Bale emaciated himself for his role in "The Machinist." He was as buff as could be in the Batman movies. Here he puts on weight and sports a near reprehensible comb-over. Amy Adams has a couple of scenes where it appears she's wearing no makeup whatsoever. How many actresses would do that? Jennifer Lawrence is just plain great. This is unlike any role I'd ever seen her in. Her knack for turning something she screwed up into something she feels she should be thanked for put me in stitches. Brad Cooper is a real weird one as the FBI agent. He, like most of the other characters, has a hair issue. Jeremy Renner, as Mayor Carl Polito manages to turn a guy from someone you're supposed to think ill of to someone you genuinely feel sorry for is spot on.

I could go on but why bore. This is about as good a movie you'll ever see and it will stand up under repeat viewings. Check it out.

It takes a while to get adjusted to the 70's, were people used comb overs rather than shaving the head like now..  But this group of people have done a great job of making you believe in them..  I go mostly because Jennifer Lawrence is in it, how a human being with real feelings that drip off her every time she talks..

All together well worth to see..  When it comes available, I will have to get the Blue Ray.  If you doubt the cost, I have had Fifth Element on tape, DVD and Blue Ray.. The things that come alive are remarkable..

"American Hustle" (hereafter "AH") is a reasonably entertaining and engrossing variation of the sturdy "Small-Time Con Man is Pushed Into the Big Leagues" plot.  The small-time con man is the paunchy and sleazy-looking Irving (Christian Bale) with ratty hair that has a life of its own.  Irving gravitates toward scams and fraudulent businesses because he remembers the racketeers and hoodlums taking advantage of his glass-selling father, and wants to be the on the winning side.  Mainly he dabbles in selling art forgeries and using the proceeds to arrange phony loans to desperate customers.  Somewhat amazingly, he attracts the romantic attention of a sultry, slinky red-haired distaff con artist Sydney Prosser (alias: Lady Edith Greensly) (Amy Adams).  Together they stage more lucrative, but still relatively low-level scams.  Irving keeps Sydney as a mistress and comforting muse and morale-booster because he is married to shrill, maritally frustrated, and seemingly dense Rosalyn Rosenfeld (Jennifer Lawrence from the "The Hunger Games") and has a young son by her.  Almost inevitably, Irving and Sydney choose the wrong mark for one of their bogus art sales - excitable, eager, but somewhat meatheaded mama's boy Richard "Richie" Dimaso, FBI Agent.

To avoid jail time, Irving and Sydney agree to help "Richie" orchestrate an "Abscam" inspired sting operation intended to expose at least four U.S. congressmen for bribery and, I think, violation of immigration laws since a "wealthy Sheik Abdullah" (actually Paco Hernandez) offers to fast-track his American naturalization process for a hefty fee.  Somehow, all this action also involves "slightly unscrupulous" New Jersey Mayor Carmine Polito (Jeremy Renner) and his desire to develop waterfront property businessess and casinos to help his constituents.  And that's the plot of AH.

Besides the reasonable pleasure of watching the scams (and counterscams and double-crosses) unfold and unravel, AH also vividly and convincingly re-creates the outlandish and kooky zeitgeist of the '70s with well-chosen '70s song classics (like Steely Dan's "Reeling in the Years" and Wings's "Live and Let Die"), the occasional parties, and introduction of new gadgets like microwaves, which Rosalyn learns are hostile to aluminum foil.  Especially, AH does not forget the hair styles.  Irving isn't the only one with follicle trouble; his wife Rosalyn's 'do looks like yellow spaghetti; Mayor Polito has the Elvis pompadour; even FBI agent Richie (in a hilarious sequence) shows how he gets all the little curls in his hair as his mother yells at him to fix the fish tank filter. Richie's exasperated and brow-beaten FBI superior and mentor Stoddard Thorsen (Louis C.K.) provides some humorous bits as he tries to stop Richie from squandering funds on an entire hotel floor for the scam, and to relate and finish an ice-fishing experience he had with his brother as a kid. Jennifer Lawrence (as Rosalyn) is a hoot as the complaining "bubblehead" who nevertheless has valid objections against Irving's treatment of her and even advises him on a Plan B when one of his cons (can't remember which one) starts to go south.  From time to time, AH also provides voice-overs (mainly from Irving but sometimes from Sydney) explaining his philosophy, his motivation, and the movie's plot.

Thus, AH has its positive qualities, but for me the movie stumbled somewhat because it fails to follow Irving's credo to work on small, simple cons.  The straightforward plot starts to wind back upon itself as cons get conned and counter-conned and players get played and counterplayed.  Robert DeNiro's fleeting and almost-stereotypical but expectedly effective portrayal of mobster Victor Tellegio wanting a piece of the "Sheik"'s action actually, I humbly think, needlessly complicates matters.  Eventually, at about the midway point, AH becomes, as another Amazon.com reviewer puts it, "yawny", and I momentarily lost track.  That was unfortunate for me, because the climax and denouement of AH, with some ironic turns and fates for characters we expected otherwise that the midway point might have explained.

Overall, I generally recommend the movie and its various retroactive pleasures (including predicaments that could have been solved by cell phones and Internet access if they had existed in the early '70s), especially the funky coiffures.  But try to keep your attention focused, because AH's con goes on and on and on, and might leave you behind if you're not careful.

3.5 stars

I saw this movie, as I usually do, by just showing up at the theatre and watching whatever movie is playing next knowing not a single thing about it.

On the positive side, the setting is 1978 and the clothes, music, cars all were done wonderfully.  I love a historical piece and this one didn't fail to show us some of the best and some of the worst from fashion in this era.  The soundtrack is diverse and appropriate and doesn't just stick to the same 20 songs we tend to hear from the late 70's.  Also, as story lines go this one was reasonably well executed and held my own interest for most of the 2+ hours.  I saw this one in a VERY crowded theatre and the audience seemed attentive and responsive to the 15-20 comedic bits.  In fact one woman in the front row very nearly choked to death on a piece of popcorn that happened to hit the wrong spot just as something funny was going on.

To the negative, the movie did have some continuity problems and the middle hour or so was a bit of a yawn-filled drag.  It seemed like a movie that was cobbled down from about 5 hours to 2 as characters made unexplained transitions between emotional states; I suspect an extended version might make slightly more sense but likely end up being fairly unbearable.

In summary, not the best movie I've seen in the past few months but it was amusing enough to justify the time spent.  Any movie featuring a comb-over as complex as the one in the opening scenes of the movie deserves at least 4 stars.

The bottom line about "American Hustle" is that for me, it was an uneven mix of drama and comedy as well as realism and escapism that left me scratching my head about what sort of movie its makers wanted it to be.  Another problem for me is the depiction of Christian Bale's character as a "nice conman" and making him the "hero" of the story and the FBI special agent as the (sort of) heavy.  Finally, the movie had a twist ending that I felt was wildly implausible and also completely dishonest with the movie's audience.

I really did want to like the movie (it had a power cast who did well with their characters...especially Christian Bales and Bradley Cooper.  Jennifer Lawrence did well as Bale's ditz of a wife although I thought she was a tad too young in the role.  The general outline of the plot was also interesting.  It depicted through a fictional lens, the Abscam investigation where the FBI (using a confidence man it recruited) ultimately caught a number of corrupt politicians, including US Congressmen and a Senator.

But I think it was a mistake to depict the story of the film from the perspective of the conman vice the FBI special agents, let alone show the FBI special agent who was his handler as an out-of-control drug abusing nutcase.  I found myself thinking, yeah, that's the way the real-life conman who Bale's character is modeled on (and who sold his "story" to the film-makers) probably remembers it, but I wonder how the FBI special agents (there were two handlers in real life) remember things.

This leads me to another thing that I really hated about "American Hustle" and which the movie "Goodfellas" which it imitates in some ways did not have...I'm talking about the ultimate fate of the protagonist and the moronic twist ending that does not play fair with viewers.

<spoilers for both "American Hustle" and "Goodfellas">

In "Goodfellas," Henry Hill gets cornered by his own stupidity and greed and facing a long stretch in prison from the Feds or a bullet in the head from his former business associates, he becomes a cooperating witness.  His friends all go to jail and he survives, but the movie ends by showing him frustrated and lost somewhere in middle America far away from the New York milieu that was his home and his marriage over.

Contrast that with the ending of "American Hustle."  The conman played by Bales suddenly has pangs of guilt over betraying a friend (the corrupt mayor of Camden).  So --and this is all done off-screen until the big "twist ending-- he manages to steal money the FBI was hoping to snare a mafia boss by staging a con against the FBI and his handler.  He then blackmails the FBI into going easy on his friend the mayor and giving him and his girlfriend a free ride on all the crimes they had committed.

One thing I hated about that was the way it was all hidden until after the fact from us the viewers.  Maybe some people don't mind a movie or a book doing something like that but I hate it.  It's a cheap trick, and it's not playing fair with the audience.  They still could have shown the "lovable" conman scamming the FBI but the viewers should have known what was going on.

(incidentally, in real life, the mayor did not get a light sentence at all but a very severe one; and the conman got very well-paid by the FBI for his work for them)

Also, I just gagged a bit at the way the movie sanitized the rather grubby real-life story of the conman after the Abscam case ended.  Yes, he and his girlfriend reconciled but their marriage eventually failed (not too surprising when the people involved were professional liars and cheats).  And his wife (Lawrence's character) wound up killing herself not long after the Abscam case became public.  Showing the conman and his girlfriend ride off into the sunset at the end of "American Hustle" made me think of the ending of an even worse movie "Tequila Sunrise" (where Mel Gibson managed to look heroic as a major league drug dealer and wound up with the girlfriend and the loot and his freedom).

<end spoilers>

So in the end, "American Hustle" is worth seeing for some great performances and some laughs along the way.  But it's nowhere near as honest a film as "Goodfellas" was.

[based upon theatre viewing, 12-30-13]

Lose 15-20 minutes of the "romance" (4 people with 2 lovers, a piece; one marriage; one imagined "bisexual" tryst) and we have a 4.5* movie!

Every time I think the movie's about to end....they *pulled* me back in!

Beautiful acting and a terrific, often hilarious screenplay. The plot, well....two criminal minded but well meaning, non violent con artists get hooked up with a well meaning but over-acheiving, rising star FBI guy [Bradley]. He cons *them* into working for *him*, after a successful sting (guess the stung guy [Christian] wasn't so non-vulnerable after all, getting "stung"...and not realizing his new squeeze [Amy] was putting on her "English accent").

FBI guy is sure his *really big* sting will get a huge Mob Guy (DeNiro) plus several Congressman, and a well meaning but easily led Mayor of Camden, NJ. Backdrop: the "new" Atlantic City, NJ, casino mecca. It's 1978 and 2,000,000 bucks goes a long way.

The movie veers from soap opera to black comedy to docu drama.

Yes, chop off 20 minutes - save it for the DVD - and you got a great movie. (And don't wonder too loud why the writers did not make Jeremy the Mayor of *Atlantic City*).

So...at the end of the day, we have a nice effort by "Quentin Scorsese". Could do worse.

note: Niro doesn't arrive until you've looked at your watch for the third time. But, damm, is he worth waiting for!

Boring, boring, then more boring.  After all the blue screen explosions and car wrecks that waste screen space these days, I was hoping for a good movie from this director and good cast, but what do we get?  Confusing plot... poor directing... lots of Amy Adams boobs... no continuity of storyline... more Amy Adams boobs... disappointing ending... below-average camera work... etc.  Did I mention Amy Adams's dresses and blouses constantly display her boobs?  Sorry to harp on it, but they're the most agreeable part of the movie when there's little else to look at.  Save your money and time.

Powerful storytelling that is delivered with dynamic directing and editing.  The film builds on its themes with a virtuoso narrative engine that intertwines three main characters.  (Four if you count Jennifer Lawrence's ... but it can be well argued that her role is more of a large supporting one.)  The interior perspectives of the characters is delivered with voice over ... a technique that can go horribly wrong, but in this film works gloriously as it gives the audience an artfully skewed experience of the point of view of each character.  A multi-prismed tale of how some incredibly desperate, deceitful, yet compelling people view themselves, their hustles, their rules, their schemes for survival ... and the hustles and schemes and lies they must navigate as they crawl their way through an ever increasing complex and layered maze of cons and realities.

Visually this film is exquisite.  The camera work is impeccable.  Cinematic eye candy that is actually substantive.  David O. Russell uses dynamic camera movement and editing that is deliberately reinforcing of the content of the scenes.  The use of period pop music is unrelenting, but it is both spry and potent throughout.  The acting is nothing short of extraordinary. Which means much credit has to be given to Russell. These are great actors he is working with, but you don't get performances like that without diligent and forceful directing.

Christian Bale delivers what I think might be his best performance so far.  Amy Adams and Jennifer Lawrence are amazing and they deliver scenes toward the end of the movie that are real firework shows.  Jeremy Renner is also wonderful.  The entire cast does an amazing job ... with a delightful and funny surprise turn by Louis C.K..

There is one false or too broad moment toward the end with an over-the-top bit of needle drop and Jennifer Lawrence's hair.  But I was so taken at that point, I was able to easily ignore it and give Russell a pass.

Yes, this movie has a popcorn sheen. But I think it's a clever and deliberate sheen that is cleverly designed to drive home fascinating themes about American ambition and self-creation.  And in that way it is very similar to Three Kings.  Another movie that appears on the surface to be just a light, popcorn action-adventure about hunting down gold in the Iraq war.  But the wonderful pop sheen is deliberately engineered to help us sit happily through a movie that really deals with dark and unpleasant elements:  greed, desperation, survival and the organ-destroying ability of bullets.  Three Kings takes on these themes on so many levels and so many manifestations -- from the goofy Spike Jonze character's absurd and pathetic ambitions to the national issues concerning ripping open a country with military might and leaving it to bleed out and its citizens to fend for themselves in the remaining wake of chaos.

American Hustle is built much the same way.  A camera-swooping, pop music-thumping, non-linear, dance-puzzle that delves into the darker aspects of conflicting realities, lies, cons and self creation.

Three Kings is a true classic.

American Hustle might very well be one as well.  It's too early to call.

David O. Russell started out as a director with a vision; he made the incredibly challenging films SPANKING THE MONKEY and THREE KINGS, and as the years went on, he seemed to tire of making films with something to say, and opted for performance-based Oscar bait. Both THE FIGHTER and SILVER LININGS PLAYBOOK are not bad films in the least, but neither of them really do anything to subvert audience expectations. Either of those films could have been directed by just about anyone. AMERICAN HUSTLE has a little of the former and a lot of the latter, but toes the line just enough to keep you interested and invested, and for once with Russell's recent films, you don't know how it's going to end.

AMERICAN HUSTLE is a highly fictionalized accounting of the real life Abscam scandals of the late 70's that involved some low to mid-level elected government officials as well as the Mob, and how it took a couple of con artists to teach the FBI how to properly catch them. You have Irving (Christian Bale) and his lover/partner Sydney aka Lady Edith (Amy Adams) as a great short-con artist team, as well as Irving's incredibly unhinged wife Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence) on the "family" side. But once Irving and Sydney are busted by young FBI agent Richie (Bradley Cooper), they're behind the eight-ball. But Richie has bigger fish he wants to fry. He's sick of government corruption and wants to go after those who want to use their elected positions to accept graft, and in Irving and Lady Edith, he sees an opportunity to learn what they have to teach. He agrees to drop the many fraud charges against them if they will assist him in four arrests, and they reluctantly agree. The first person Richie wants to go after is Carmine Polito (Jeremy Renner), the beloved family-man mayor of Camden, New Jersey. Polito seems to be looking to get funds to assist with the renovation of Atlantic City to help create thousands of jobs his constituents desperately need. Once it gets to a certain point, though, thanks in no small part to the emotionally manipulative Rosalyn and the increasingly desperate Richie, Irving and Sydney seem to have no way out of what they themselves have been manipulated into.

Russell keeps the film at a really solid rhythm all throughout, and the actors, including Louie C.K. as Richie's FBI superior and a cameo by Robert De Niro as a feared Miami mob underboss, are all stellar. Bale continues to amaze with another chameleonic performance; Cooper gives what I would consider to be the performance of his career; Lawrence keeps hitting the bullseye film after film and is arguably the strongest actor of her generation and this performance is no exception; Renner gets past his misstep from being in HANSEL AND GRETEL: WITCH HUNTERS to being more on par with the performances he's given in the past. The strongest performer here for me is Adams, who always does incredibly solid work, but here, she's given a role within a role that she plays with gusto, intelligence, sexiness, and total confidence.

My main complaint about this film, though, is how it really does seem to be Scorsese-lite. Many indie filmmakers seem to feel the need to ape Scorcese at some point in their careers, and while it works in this film, I would have liked much more to see a film that was more of Russell's and less of a 70's-era homage.

All in all, AMERICAN HUSTLE is exciting and entertaining filmmaking that could have used a boost of originality, but let's face it: Russell seems to really just want to get that Oscar. Or if not him, than at least his cast.

4.5 out of 5 stars.

Since The Fighter and Silver Linings Playbook,director David O. Russell can do no wrong in the site of the Academy Awards. And unfortunately they'll be handing out nominations to this like candy to kids on Halloween. Here he tries to be stylistic for once by ripping off directors like Martin Scorsese and Paul Thomas Anderson and fails miserably. A disappointment!

Overall, I liked this film. Good writing, direction, and cinematography. I'll keep my eye on this director. Basically, this is a snitch flick with a moral, that is, when it comes to good and bad there's just varying shades of gray. Christian Bale and Amy Adams play grifters who are caught and become Federal snitches in an attempt to avoid lengthy prison sentences. Bradley Cooper plays the Federal  agent they must work with to entrap a network of very powerful and dangerous individuals ranging from mafiosos and politicians including an idealistic mayor effectively portrayed by Jeremy Renner who bares a strong resemblance to Joe Pesci's "Tommy" in Goodfellas. As I said earlier, the operative word in understanding this movie and its cast of "good" and "bad" guys is gray, because there are no sharp distinctions between the protagonists and antagonists in the film. This is what makes a film interesting and what separates films like these from "Summer" movies.

There were surprises in this film, not from the film, which I did not find original or groundbreaking in any way. Nothing very special about the film itself. What surprised me was the commitment Bale gave to his role. He looked downright sloppy and very pathetic, very true to his role in the film. As he did in The Mechanic, he morphed his body to fit the role of his character. Another surprise was seeing DeNiro, looking very old, very much his age as an old gangster.

The soundtrack fit the scenes perfectly. My favorite scene was a slow mo scene to Elton John's "Goodbye Yellow Brick Road." However, after a while the music felt like forced melodrama and became both predictable and annoying, though not enough to cancel out the film's positives. The cinematography was gorgeous and captured the feeling and period of the film. This was a Christmas Eve date film I wasn't excited about seeing but was very grateful I didn't miss after the credits rolled. Can't wait for it to come out on Blu ray.

David O. Russle wrote some pretty good movies. So he decided to write another one with basically all of the other actors that to work with him. None of the actors need introductions, and they all do an excellent job and the reason it's so praised is because of the dialogue and the actors ability to act. David enjoys writing movies with crazy characters, and this film over-indulged the idea. It's like he wanted to make a "super-movie" with all his actors, and it detracts from some of the other actors because it feels over crowded. It's also nominated for a golden globe for best comedy and if I didn't know that, then I wouldn't know it was a comedy. It's not a bad movie and has a pretty awesome ending but not worth the hype it's getting.

Not only does the music bring back the late 70s of everything from Duke Ellington to disco, but the costumes positively reek of it, from velour for men to shameless for women. Christian Bale and Amy Adams are absolutely first rate, and Jennifer Lawrence gets a juicy stereotype to munch on.

But mostly, there is the story. Hustlers being outhustled and ending up being dragged into a hustle way out of their league. It's a long, involved process, and remarkably, it grips you throughout the length (2:09) of the film. The music helps, but the story stars. You have to pay attention, and it's worth it. The characters are clever and sharp, they live by their wits. They are pleasure to follow for once.

And the risk is real, for once. Any and all of the characters could lose out, right up to their lives. That gives the film extra power, compared to all the superhero and comic book characters who you know must come through no matter what. So suspense plays a significant role too.

You have take notice of the hair, of all things. Everyone's hair gets talked about, and there are several scenes of the characters doing their hair, particularly the men. Unlike today's rather conformist close cropped or shaved head, the 70's were exuberant, American Hustle is an exuberant piece of entertainment.

David Wineberg

Nine Things about American Hustle

1. This is a masterful film of American ambition woven into a gorgeous tapestry of 1970s style, fashion and music.

2. It is about ego, honor, self-improvement, and the necessity to re-invent oneself in order to make it in this dog-eat-dog world.

3. The story centers on Christian Bale, who plays a petty con artist named Irving. The movie starts off by detailing Irvings criminal career and his reluctant involvement with federal law enforcement.

4. Irving is also having problems at home, which leads him to fall for his partner in crime. While Irving wants to keep his professional and personal lives separate, they inevitably end up on a collision course with each other, and Irving ends up playing for much higher stakes than he ever wanted to.

5. For all the sleaziness of the story and characters, the movie has no nudity or blood. This is storytelling magic that doesnt rely on sex or violence to keep you interested.

6. This means that people who need sex and violence in their movies will likely be kind of bored.

7. Everything in the movie, from the fashion, to the hairstyles, to the story, to the actors performances, are slightly exaggerated, just a little bit larger than life. Not enough to turn into a caricature, but just enough to make everything seem to vibrate. The fact that the actors can actually pull this all off is amazing  the acting is uniformly brilliant, and there are no weak links in the cast.

8. The movie takes the old American concept of being a self-made man and cranking it up a notch. The characters are always looking out for themselves, and soon nobody knows who is on what side or if there are even any sides at all.

9. This is a movie not only about how we fool each other, but how we lie to ourselves, which is the biggest con of all.

David O. Russell just sounds like one of those 1970s directors, or maybe its David O. Selznick Im thinking about, who was a great producer in the 30s and 40s of many Hitchcock films, "King Kong" and most notably "Gone with the Wind". So David O. Russell really doesnt compare to Selznick other than the similarity of name and the fact that the big O in the middle seems to signify an association with quality films and Oscar nominated and winning films.

Russell has been flirting with Oscar trophies for 3-years now. First he directed "The Fighter", then "Silver Linings Playbook" and now he will most certainly be nominated for a third time for "American Hustle". He may not win again, but it would be a safe bet that at least one of the actors he cast in "Hustle" will walk away with trophy. While Bradley Cooper, Amy Adams, Christian Bale and Jeremy Renner were all outstanding in their performances, Id have to admit, it was Jennifer Lawrence that plays the smaller role in the film and steals the scene every time she appears.

"American Hustle" is a throwback to when films about heists, swindles and double-crosses were the talk of the town. Its the kind of film that tests your true love for cinema. As the film plays out and we swirl around in Irving Rosenfeld (Bale) and Sydney Prosser (Adams) a.k.a Lady Edith Greenslys worlds, its like a test of patience. Irving and Sydney find themselves getting deeper and deeper into trouble and the movie is exhausting with the banter, plots and plans. Your head will be literally spinning just hoping to keep up with their mess. While it was slow moving and littered with a barrage of oncoming information, its exactly how you should feel watching the film, because it is exactly what Irving and Sydney are dealing with.

"Hustle" is a dance along the fine line that is right and wrong; survival and ruin. It is exactly what happens when a script, that should be nominated for an Oscar by the way, can either be mundane and boring or lifted above that by the performers of the roles. The performers in "American Hustle" do just that and then some. With humor and passion and great writing, you get caught up in the tornado of right and wrong, trying to figure out how to get off, just like Irving and Sydney.

I don't know what everyone else expected out of this movie, but I expected a little more. The acting was great as it should have been with that all-star cast and the production quality and styling of the late 1970's was equally good. The story however felt a little anticlimactic and unfocused. Having been at least partially based on a true story the payoff wasn't as big as expected. Something that didn't help it's case was the cinematography. The film could have been much more aesthetically pleasing, maybe David O Russell was too focused on making the film look 'indie'. One of the best things the movie had going for it was the sometimes subtle comedy, however the overall re-watch factor didn't really seem that high to me.

Theatrical review.  There may be spoilers.

I think I got my first laugh at the beginning of this movie when a tag line appears saying something to the effect of "Some of the things seen here actually happened."  Director David O. Russell and his co-writer, Eric Singer, make no bones about the fact they are making most of this up.  What is true and the basis of the film is the FBI entrapment scheme of the late 1970's called Abscam.  Several New Jersey congressmen, a U. S. senator and local officials were implicated in a bribe scandal to fast-track an Arab's American citizenship and other misdeeds.

In the movie the creator of the plot is Irving Rosenfeld (Christian Bale).  Bale is a far cry from his Dark Knight character, complete with a large beer belly and an atrocious comb over.  Irving is assisted by his mistress, Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams).  They've been coerced by the FBI to pull off the scheme in order to get a pass on another crime which is their real pay day.  Essentially they sell fake art and obtain large deposits to get loans for people with no other access to credit.

The film has a similar feel as Russell's brilliant "Silver Linings Playbook" from 2012.  In fact he recruits Bradley Cooper, Jennifer Lawrence and Robert De Niro from that film.  Cooper plays the ambitious but inept FBI agent who leads the effort.  Lawrence, in another remarkable performance, is Irving's wife Rosalyn, complete with a piled high bee-hive hairdo.  De Niro has a small but very convincing role as the Miami based mobster who wants in on the action.

The film has the smart but formally uneducated group outfitted in the finest of the era.  Ugly by most accounts; still I have to say I certainly liked the slinky Halston-styled dresses.  The kind with a deep V-cut and a style that banished the bra.  Jeremy Renner does well as Camden Mayor Polito.  His hair almost reaches the heights of Rosalyn's.  The film is funny, dramatic and has some excellent individual scenes, especially those that include Ms. Lawrence.  To be sure this is a terrific film.  Well written with some authentic sets and designs and some solid performances.

Who ever say bad things or say negative things about Bradley cooper well they are dead wrong! He was the fantastic in this movie and also not a fan of Christian bale never liked him. Plus he looked gross lol. I liked Amy Adams and her and Bradley were hot together. Jennifer Lawrence was surprisingly good. Even tho I'm not a fan of her either. This movie is worth a watch and yes Bradley is a fantastic actor and really hot:) love him
